Posts.Content: Don't panic Hun, it just takes time and the initial growth takes the longest. I recall getting fed up of people say "wow your hair is really starting to grow now" when all I could see was a short grey fuzz! But it is growing it just takes time! You'll get there Hun. Have a (((((((((hug)))))))) it won't solve your problems but it might just make you feel supported  I hope xxxx
Posts.Title: Want hair back

Posts.Content: Hi Mandymoo76, I would either call or email PALS at your hospital, explain to them what you have said on here and they will contact the BCN or the surgeon for you. I had issues a while ago and reached breaking point, I couldn't contact anyone and so blurted all my issues out to them. Within a day or two they had information, I had an email from surgeon a call from the nurse and a lot of apologies! But it got the ball rolling and made me feel they were doing something and I hadn't been forgotten. I don't understand the need for another biopsy? If they already know it's cancer? Surely they are going to operate so why more biopsies! Think I would be asking more questions...through pals! Hope that helps a little, or at least makes you feel someone is listening. Pick up that phone Hun and get some answers.  Good luck xxxx
Posts.Title: What are you supposed to do? :(

Posts.Content: Hi Pootlecav, I'm really sorry to hear how low you are feeling. I think my first piece of advice would be to go back to your GP and explain how you are really feeling. its not really for your GP to tell you when you are ready to return to work. Yes they can say if you are physically ready, although even that can vary from person to person. But they certainly can't tell if you are emotionally ready, only you know that. Are you going back to a phased return? What sort of work do you do? If it's something you really don't enjoy, maybe it's time to find a new job, for a fresh start! I know even that can feel very daunting! I think you need to decide whether you really don't feel up to going back or if it's just because you are scared you are going back to your old life that you weren't enjoying! Sometimes we have to face our fears to give us the push we need to make life changing decisions. Maybe when you go back you will find ways to improve the way you feel about your job, or maybe it will give you the push/drive to find something new. Sorry if that doesn't help much, I have always been lucky enough to do a job i love! So for me the bigger fear was the fear I would never work in the same role again. We are all different and we all have different ways of looking at things. You have to find a solution to suit you a solution that makes you happy. After all you have been through its time to LIVE not just to EXIST! I want to offer you a ((((((((((supportive hug)))))))))) We may not be able to solve your problems but everyone on here is here to support you and offer a shoulder to cry on. We all have bad days/weeks/months but you will get through them and you will find that positive, happy life you yearn for. Why else would you of just fought the biggest fight of your life! Xxxxx
Posts.Title: Starting again but so low

Posts.Content: I think you need this today....... YOU ARE NEVER ALONE HUN xxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Starting again but so low

Posts.Content: I recall going through a phase when everyone felt the need to touch my soft baby fluff hair  So bloody annoying! But I smiled through! Oh and just to cheer you up......I'm now a few years on and back to moaning about bad hair days  never bloomin satisfied  xxxx
Posts.Title: Want hair back

Posts.Content: Hi, I went back in after my origional surgery to have my node clearance surgery. I didn't have the blue dye done again, although was still sporting my blue tit look from the first surgery. I believe the dye is just for them to view which are the first few nodes. Not needed when they are going in to remove all the nodes! But saying that my surgery was over 3 years ago and things change!  Good luck with your surgery xxxx
Posts.Title: Radio active dye during lymph node removal

Posts.Content: Hi, it is still very early days, I know 10 weeks seems a long time but when you think about what your body has been through, it's not that long! I recall having that feeling of something being stuck in my arm pit, a very odd sensation, but it does eventually go. Keep going with the exercises as they really do help. As for Lymphoedema just keep an eye. I would say it's unlikely as it 'usually' affects the arm or breast. I have Lymphoedema in both arm and breast but interestingly the shoulder isn't affected! I would give it a few more weeks and see how it goes, keep an eye on your arm, if you want to be super vigilant you could record some measurements now and check again in a few weeks! That way IF you were still concerned you would have something to show them! I hope it is just swelling from the surgery, it takes time for everything to get back to normal. I know I had odd feelings and sensations for months. But it will settle eventually. Hope that helps a little (((((((((hug)))))))) xxx
Posts.Title: Axillary clearance post surgery swelling or lymphodema?

Posts.Content: ronstar On a plus she said any crankiness and low mood I might experience on Tamoxifen is down to sleep deprivation and not the drug itself!  Hi Hun, hope you are doing okay. Saw the above comment and sorry I couldn't ignore! Has this Physio had breast cancer? Has she actually taken the drug herself?  I took it for 18months and for me, and of course we are all different, the Tamoxifen caused the lack of sleep and the low mood! How do I know? Because when I stopped taking it, just 3 days later my mood lifted, I went from feeling like my life wasn't worth living to the happy person I used to be, bearing in mind I had also just found out my Cancer had spread to the bone, I had every reason to feel down but I didn't. After 18months of feeling rubbish I felt human again! I'm not saying Tamoxifen is horrible for everyone in fact most people get on fine with it, but for some people, like me the Drug did cause these issues, it wasn't the sleep deprivation!  I am still NOT sleeping properly but my mood on the whole is fine. On Tamoxifen I was awful. Hope I haven't spoken out of turn. But I got really frustrated by hearing things like that being said to me by my GP or BCN or Oncologist.........I felt I was going mad because no one seemed to agree it was the drug causing this!  As I said we are all different and I hope you sail through with minimal issues  xxx As for work, WORRIED2016 and ronstar I wouldn't rush into anything. If you are able to delay things, I would consider that. Or maybe try part time?! If that is possible. Sending love to you both xx
Posts.Title: Being fit and well is such a long way off

Posts.Content: I would suggest taking as long as you need! I worked throughout treatment (my choice) so my energy levels dropped, but I managed to work it into my daily routine. So it was fine! My problems began when I changed jobs and then found I might have bone mets! That is the point I discovered I hadn't really given myself time to come to terms with exactly what I had just been through and was going to be continuing to go through! I then took a year off! Some of it was spent getting over surgery, the rest of it I just relaxed and took it easy!  I started back at work, a new job on Tuesday this week and it was tough but it was very enjoyable to be back to 'my new normal'!  I think you need to work out if you need to work, what sort of work you would like, and then start with minimal hours and work your way up slowly As for Cancer affecting your chances of getting a job.....in some places sadly it will. But other places will hire you, because you are able to do the job! The perfect job will be out there, when you are ready for it! Xxx helsbels, Good Luck with your first day back, I hope it goes well  xxx
Posts.Title: Returning to work? How soon?

Posts.Content: Hi Hun, firstly you are by no way a wimp, so don't think that. As for whether you give it another go, that's your call. You need to decide whether it's worth the discomfort for the next 5 sessions, or whether you can get your head around the idea of losing your hair! Although I will add, others don't need to see you bald....there are some amazing wigs around and so there's no reason why you shouldn't still appear perfectly 'normal' around others! I decided against cold capping, because I couldn't face the extended time in the chemo unit and the thought of having to be extra careful with my hair during those 18wks was just too much for me! Dealing with the chemo was enough! I went from waist length hair to bald in a couple of weeks  Yes I cried and felt self conscious for a bit, then I brushed myself off and realised that in the whole scheme of things, hair wasn't that big a deal after all, plus it would and has grown back! It's a very personal decision, but I hope you make one that leaves you able to get through the next few weeks without any added stress. Sending you a (((((((((supportive hug)))))))) xxxx
Posts.Title: Any thoughts on the cap to avoid hair falling out?

Posts.Content: No prob Hun, it just hit a nerve! I'm currently on Zoladex injections and they are no picnic in the park either! But for ME better than Tamoxifen!  As for my first week in new job....... Hmmmmmmmmm think the word is EXHAUSTED! Looking forward to a lie in on Saturday......not that I'll sleep, that would be a miracle  xxx
Posts.Title: Being fit and well is such a long way off

Posts.Content: Good for you Jo  two fingers up to Cancer! Enjoy your Family Christmas.......they are far more important than Cancer cells. Let the Chemo deal with those, you concentrate on having fun  xxxx
Posts.Title: New day, new attitude

Posts.Content: Hi JayDee, totally understand! I was on Tamoxifen for 20months, the longest and unhappiest 20months of my life! When I was told I could stop the Tamoxifen the oncologist said don't expect too much too soon, it'll take a while to get the drug out of your system......by day 3 I felt like 'me' again! I felt I had been released from a sort of living nightmare, back in to my old life! That drug may be doing a great job at keeping Cancer away (not for me) but it can affect your body in a huge way, it's only when you stop it that you realise what it was truly doing! I am on Zoladex injections now, which sadly have put me back in that horrid place, but it's not quite as bad as the Tamoxifen. I have no choice about taking this drug as I now have secondaries.  It's really difficult to start taking a drug again, when you know how you felt without it. All you can do is remind yourself of what it's hopefully doing! You do have a choice, but obviously it comes with risks and you need to think how you would cope if you stopped the tablets and the cancer came back.....could you cope with that or would you blame yourself!! Good Luck with whatever you decide! ((((((((((Understanding hug))))))))))) xxx
Posts.Title: Six week break from Tamoxifen .....

Posts.Content: yesterday I finally faced the fact that I have Secondary Breast Cancer and that it will always be with me. So however much I TRY to continue on and pretend it's not there, it is, and it always will be! I have believed all along that the best way to fight this disease was to pretend it wasn't really happening. To continue on as normal. Yesterday was different, I woke after a rough night feeling exhausted. I HAD to lift my heavy legs out of bed as I had to go to work! I wanted to go to work, but a part of me just felt it was too much effort. After I was dressed and I stood in the kitchen counting out my drugs for the morning, I cried.......cried because I felt so tired and so fed up, that at just 41 (okay almost 42) I was stood there first thing in the morning feeling absolutely exhausted. However at the same time wanting to go to work, to do the job I am good at and that I love! It was at that point I realised, I wasn't the same person anymore, I wasn't a fit and healthy 41year old, I was a 41 year old, who was just getting over a chest infection, just starting a new job after 1 year off, living with pain everyday, coping with hot flushes, lack of sleep, mood swings, Lymphoedema and the BIG one......the one I have ignored for so long......most of this caused by drugs that I HAVE to take to keep my Cancer under control! However annoying they are they are hopefully going to keep me alive for a long time, but the pay off is, I have to remember I do have Cancer and I can't be as physically or emotionally strong as I used to be!  This is the new me, and according to my new boss I'm still pretty darn good at my job! We had a good chat, and I now feel relaxed and calm about things........for the first time in 3.5years!  So my reason for writing this, well I like to assume that I'm not the only person who has struggled to TRULY admit what has or is happening to them! So maybe someone else will read this and allow themselves to change the way they think about themselves. We are surrounded by people telling us "how brave we are", "how strong we are" etc etc when I personally just needed to tell myself that this journey isn't about being strong or brave, it's about being HONEST about admitting that the new you, won't ever be exactly like the old you, and that that's okay! Because in some ways the new you is BETTER, WISER and definitely more CARING and UNDERSTANDING than the old you, ever was! It might be physically worse off, in some cases, but you know what, that's okay too.......just do what you can from day to day, after all as my grandmother always said "there's another day tomorrow"!  So now I intend to wear my heart on my sleeve, I will admit to myself that I'm not superhuman, I will ask for support when I need it, I will speak out when I need help! Because I am very much 'living with Cancer' and other people need to understand how hard that is sometimes! It's nothing to be ashamed of it's nothing to hide, in fact maybe if we spoke more openly about Cancer it wouldn't continue to scare people the way it seems to at the moment! My boss was very open to hearing how I felt and I'm sure there are many more people like her. I don't want tilted heads and the sympathetic looks, but at the same time if we actually admit we are living and working with Cancer, we show others that we are still very much alive and well! If that makes sense!!  Now I should really think about getting up! Time to enjoy my lazy weekend! Hope you all have a good one

Posts.Title: Letrozole tumour symptoms

Posts.Content: Hi ronstar, sorry to hear you have had such a tough day, hopefully tomorrow will be easier for you. I had a couple of days through my Radiotherapy where I left in tears! As a rule the staff were amazing, but on one occasion they had some 'manager' in who needed to check how they were doing things! I had already been lined up, but she needed to check everything and redo it. I was lying half naked for 45mins, with 6 people in the room (male and female). I wasn't asked if this was okay and couldn't say anything as I had a tube in my mouth as I was using a breath hold technique. I had a lot to say afterwards and made it very clear that this was not how patients should be treated! The manager was VERY apologetic, but it was too little too late! I still got through my 35 sessions! Even managed a laugh on some of the days. So please don't lose heart. Tell them how hard today was and how upset you were. I know they need to do their job, but you need to feel they care. Sending you strength and best wishes for tomorrow Hun (((((((hug)))))) xxxx

Posts.Title: Just so fed up - will it ever end?

Posts.Content: Hi Hun, sounds like you need another appointment with your surgeon, for him/her to explain things properly! Your results were good, you had no node involvement which is a good sign. It means it's highly likely the cancer was contained within the breast. Which obviously is no longer there. Whoch is why they haven't offered Chemo.  As for IF it comes back would it be incurable......NO it wouldn't necessarily become incurable. It could return in the other breast which would be classed as another primary and treated in that way. It would still be curable if it was contained to the breast or breast and nodes. You could be treated with Chemo and Radiotherapy. The only time it would be classed as incurable is if it returned in your Bones, Lungs, Liver or any other organs of the body. BUT even then it is very much treatable. Currently you have the best treatment. Hormone therapy! It will hopefully prevent any other areas of cancer forming. So please don't think this isn't 'good treatment' because it is. It keeps many women Cancer free for a long time. I think you just need to give yourself chance to work through what you have just been through. You had Cancer and it was a very scary time. I know everyone around you probably thinks you are back to normal, but we all know that you have a long way to go yet!  Remember we are all here to listen. But right now I think you need..... Sal xxxxx

Posts.Title: Concerned about treatment plan.

Posts.Content: Hi all, hope everyone is having a lovely weekend.  I received a letter this morning to say My new breast surgeon who I met a few weeks ago has requested a mammogram, the appointment is the 19th Jan!  Now when I left the appointment with him, he said all was fine and he would write to my previous Oncologist and pass me on to their oncologist (who I see on the 17th) but from his point of view, I wouldn't need to see him again until June, when my annual mammogram would be due! So not sure why I have been sent this appointment? I don't have a BCN at this hospital, yet! So I don't really have anyone to contact! I really don't want this mammogram if I don't really need it! My breasts are so sore and the last thing I need is to have them squished again! Unless I really have to! But I won't know the reason behind this sudden letter unless I can speak to someone......but who? I see the Oncologist on the 17th at which point I assume I might meet my new BCN? So do I just leave it till then? And then ask about the reason behind the mammogram request? Or should I try and find out before then? Just as I thought things were settling this stupid letter has caused more anguish! It really does feel never ending! Especially as he didn't mention a mammogram at my appointment with him! So why the sudden change?
Posts.Title: Who would you contact?

Posts.Content: Thanks, think you might be right! It will play on my mind but only because it was never mentioned!! I was quite happy thinking my appointment on the 17th would hopefully be my last appt for a while! I've been scanned, mammogrammed and ultrasounded from head to toe.......don't imagine they really need to repeat anything! Surely they can pass over the scans and mammo results!! Repeating them would seem a waste of money! (And more painful for me)  xxx
Posts.Title: Who would you contact?

Posts.Content: Hi callmebruce, i’m Sorry your wife finds herself in this position. I too took Tamoxifen but sadly still developed Secondaries in the bone! However I just wanted to add, bone mets can be very well treated/managed. I don’t know how advanced your wife’s mets are. But I have been ‘living’ with Secondaries to the bone for 3years now and fingers crossed, things have remained stable during that whole time(awaiting scan results)! I currently have the Zoladex injections to shut down my ovaries, as my Cancer is ER+ but that’s all.  I have been offered a bone strengthening drug but have declined it at this point as a DEXA scan showed my bones are currently strong! But if and when that changes I have that drug and Letrozole waiting in the wings to take on any changes that might happen! In fact there is a long list of treatments that I will hopefully not need for a long time yet, but that are there if and when required.  I think the biggest piece of advice I can offer is, don’t assume the Physical Cancer is the most difficult part in all this. Yes having cancer is physically exhausting some days, but it is also emotionally exhausting and frustrating some days too! In fact most days (for me)! ’Living’ from scan appointment to scan appointment is tough, it will be a tough time for both of you. But take time out to talk, whether to each other, to counsellors, specialist nurses or on here. Just don’t bottle things up. You are both in this for the long haul, which is great news.......but there will be days when it doesn’t feel like goods news. Days when she’ll need that extra hug and a reminder that you are in this together and that she’s not alone! Secondary Cancer can be a very solitary place some times. But together you will learn to ‘live’ with this disease, NOT die from it!  Hoping that made some sense. Wishing you both all the best on this long journey. Sal xx
Posts.Title: Supporting partner though secondary BC

Posts.Content: My last mammogram was with the London Hospital, but I assumed that everything would be sent to the new hospital!  The surgeon didn't mention anything about needing to repeat any tests or scans?! Thanks for asking xx

Posts.Title: Spine MRI tomorrow can't eat, sleep, concentrate.

Posts.Content: how VERY Special this community is. I've been on this site, since my secondaries diagnosis, so approximately a year. During that time I have been supported through the lows and congratulated on the highs! I have tried to help and support others, in return for how supported I have felt. Over the last week I have been struggling, so I disappeared off to 'The Room' to off load, then I sneaked on to the secondary breast cancer board, as I know less people post on there. I just needed to find someone who could tell me it was okay to feel the way I did, and of course I did get some very nice responses. Today someone replied to one of my old posts, A Pledge to Myself......I received the email notification and then viewed the old post. I re-read it and realised that I was breaking 'some' of my own rules. It gave me the kick up the backside that I needed, while I'm going through a rough spot. My reason for writing this now, is to say to all of you, that even those of us who 'seem' to be doing so well, have off days. I have recently received so many positive comments about how my words have helped others, and of course that's always nice to here. But I feel I need to admit to you all and myself, that I have BAD days/weeks too. I scurried off to the two other areas because I was afraid to admit I was struggling. Now I realise that it may actually help others to know that it's okay to have off days, that it's not something you need to hide, in fact trying to hide your true feelings doesn't help anyone, especially not yourself.  So I have given myself a slap on the wrist and a good talking too. I still feel a bit shakey and worried about meeting my new team tomorrow, but whether tomorrow brings positive news or negative news, I know I can come on here and share. Because there will always be someone who understands or who will offer a virtual hug, or hand to hold. My family and friends will never truly understand how I feel, even if I was to be totally honest with them. But as long as I am open and honest with you all, I'm sure I can get past the bumps in the road, but only if I tell you about them! So I promise, no more hiding away if I need some support, no more trying to protect others from my bad times! Because I don't want any of you to feel you can't admit when times are hard. I want you to know that even those of us who 'seem' to be doing so well, have off days too. But sometimes we (or at least I) find it hard to admit  Sorry xxxx
Posts.Title: Now I know.....

Posts.Content: Oh Shellian, I think i need to say this........ There are times in life when no one can offer you a solution, because in all honesty there isn't one! None of us can give you your old life back, let's face it if we could none of us would be here! All that we can do is support each other through the tough days/weeks and remind each other that for every 'bad' day there will be lots of good days too! on the darkest days it's difficult to find that light at the end of the tunnel, but it is there. But sometimes you need others to take your hand and lead you too it and guess what, by posting on here you will find that helping hand. Day or night someone will be with you!  Today is a hard day, hopefully tomorrow will be a better day! Do something nice just for you! Treat yourself to something even if it's just a nice long bath with bubble bath and candles! Or a coffee with a friend or if you don't want to go out invite a friend over! Or just give your daughter a great big hug! Find just one thing to make you smile! Go on give it a try!! Then let us know how you got on! I'm leading you to that light Hun, it might be a long slow walk (as I'm feeling tired and achy today) but we WILL get you there! Sal xxxx
Posts.Title: Everything going wrong so many things to worry about.

Posts.Content: Oh Helen, please try not to worry too much as has already been said, if it's the scan itself you are scared of then please tell the staff and they will support you and take things slowly. Going into such a confined space isn't easy. But remember if at any point you feel you've had enough or you need some reassurance then you just tell them that!  I found closing my eyes and taking slow deep breaths helped. I also counted the rep sounds the machine was making. It sounded like a weird building site to me! In some hospitals I believe you can get music, but not the one I was in! I just got ear plugs but it was still quite loud!  Although once I found out what was making all that noise I felt much more relaxed. Now it's actually top secret and they don't really like everyone to know. But Helen I think you need to know what's causing all the sounds you are about to hear, so that as you are lying there you will be able to picture this............ See the noises are nothing to worry about, it's just the staff letting off steam!! You CAN do this HUN! You know you can! Sal xx

Posts.Title: Now I know.....

Posts.Content: Hi Shellian, sorry to hear you are feeling so down. I get the feeling from your post that this has been going on a little while? Correct me if I am wrong! But if it has and things seem to be getting worse than I think it's probably time to seek some proffessional help, as well as support from this site!  You seem to be reading a lot in to what others are thinking and feeling! I'm sure when your friends ask about when you might be returning to work, it's not because they are jealous of your time off but perhaps because they can see how unhappy and down you appear and feel that getting back to work could help?! I don't know you or your friends so forgive me if I am totally wrong! Is there a reason you can't work? Or are you just not ready too......which is fine and totally understandable!  It really sounds like you are surrounded by so many 'little' problems that are gradually turning into huge problems because you have so much time to think about them! You sound like you are surrounded by friends who are trying to understand but are failing to offer you the support you need at the moment, through no fault of their own! They haven't been through this so they could never understand! I think seeing your GP and explaining how you are feeling might open up access to some counselling if you feel talking would help. Or they can point you in the direction of CA who might be able to help with the financial issues, or where to access whatever support you feel would help you!  But the main thing I am trying to say Hun is that you don't have to do this alone! There is help and support there for you if and when you decide you need it and I totally understand how scary it is to take that first step in admitting you need support! Now I shall offer you a ((((((((((((((((supportive hug)))))))))))))))) it won't solve anything but I hope it shows you that 'someone' cares about you and more importantly someone is REALLY listening to you! Take care Hun. Sal xxxxxx

Now all I need is for all of you to pop along to the hospital tomorrow and sit with me through my appointment  Any takers?! I think my biggest problem is I hate change, I am a routine based Gal, I like to know where I am and what I'm doing. The London hospital might of been useless, but I knew their system, I knew my way round and I felt comfortable there! This hospital looks really nice from the outside, and the staff in the breast surgery bit seemed nice. So am hoping the Oncology team will be just as nice. But the uncertainty is difficult to deal with. I have written down everything I need to discuss but then wonder whether I should mention EVERYTHING at this appointment? I don't want them to think I'm a bit OTT! But at the same time I am at a point where I need to feel in control of all this, I can't drop back in to my old ways of just agreeing to everything, of that makes sense?  I want to do what's best for me.....but that means physically and emotionally best. I want to continue to live my life feeling happy! I want to try and get the pain sorted and in a perfect world I would appreciate a bit more sleep too.......and less hot flushes, or at least less severe!! Too much to ask for?! Anyway I will report back tomorrow, although won't be until late as I'm working till 9pm, it's going to be a long long day!  Thanks again for the messages, sending ((((((((((((hugs))))))))))) to you all. Xxxx

Posts.Title: Now I know.....

Posts.Content: Hi Tracey, I had issues with my feet for months after my Chemo finished. For me it was like they were burning, very painful after walking just a short distance and standing still was almost impossible!  So I used to wear 2 pairs of socks and put those cushioned shoe liners in my shoes, which helped.  At night I smothered them in moisteriser and put a sock on over the top, so the cream would be absorbed through the night. Which definitly helped me! As for being back to normal....sadly it doesn't work like that. Unfortunately people around us don't really understand, and why would they? They haven't been through it! You have to allow yourself time to get through the emotional side of all this. For some that involves counselling, for others it's just a case of finding a way of getting your true feelings out and dealing with them.  Just remember you are never alone, we are all here to listen, if you need us  xxxxx

Posts.Content: Hi Sam (Mumof3plusoh), firstly great name and hope you are being spoilt today ;-) As for the pain it could be you have pulled a muscle without realising it, or the muscle was pulled around during surgery, they aren't gentle once you are knocked out! Either way it's definitely worth mentioning at your appointment on Tuesday! Have you been keeping up with the exercises that they give you after surgery? Posts.Content: Hi Gillian, oh the joys of waiting for tests and then the results. Life before breast cancer was so much easier! However, bear in mind this could just be a bad chest infection. There are a lot of nasty bugs going around. I had a cough and cold that lasted over a month. Then came back a week later! Such a nightmare! So we have fingers crossed its nothing serious! However IF and its a big IF, it turns out to be metastasises from the BC then it IS treatable! It's not like having Lung Cancer! It will be treated how your BC was treated. So it's highly likely you WILL be around to see your grandchildren grow up! Its totally normal to have all these horrid thoughts going around in your head. But it's a waste of time and energy! So off load here and then try and put it to one side and keep busy! Difficult when you feel rough I know! Maybe watch some rubbish tv or a box set! We are all here for you, ready to listen, advise or just for.......... Theres always someone here to listen! Take Care Hun! Sal xxxx
Posts.Title: Possible lung cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Jane, I could of written your post myself! I finished Chemo the end of Feb 2014! I have suffered with pain and side effects from the Chemo, radiotherapy and hormone therapies. BUT BEFORE EVERYONE PANICS........it's not been constant. It comes and goes. The radiotherapy has caused issues with hardening in my breast which proves uncomfortable at times. I also have Lymphoedema!  So I can totally understand your feelings on all this and I understand how you feel about not feeling happy! I was surrounded with family and a couple of friends throughout, although family were only via the phone and occasional visits, basically I did this on my own, and it was bloody hard. Every time I hit a memorable anniversary I think back to where I was and how far I have come. Does that make me happy? No not really, in fact the opposite it makes me see how Cr*p all this was, and at times continues to be. I allow myself time to feel sad, to cry to wish things were different.  But then I get back up dust myself off and look to what I have achieved and enjoy the fact that I am still here and I am surrounded by people that love and care for me, and more importantly people that I love and care for. I think about how much control I have regained, how I am now 'living' with my Cancer (I have secondary cancer) and it's not controlling me anymore. I don't panic at every little pain, I don't just say yes to every thing the doctor offers. I research things I consider side effects and I work out whether it's something I can live with. I will NEVER forget, the day I was told I had Cancer, or the day I had surgery or the first Chemo or my first Radiotherapy etc etc etc......but you know what the one big thing that you can take from all this, is that you are still here you are currently NED and you are still living your life! Allow yourself time to mourn your past, but don't allow the Cancer that you HAD to destroy your future! It's hard to ignore every ache and pain, but the reality is IF it's a pain that comes and goes it's likely to be due to over doing it, just like aches and pains happened before you had cancer! I hate to say this as I'm a year older next Sat, but (((((whispers)))))) we aren't getting any younger  But the side effects from the hormone drugs will be making everything worse. I think it sounds like you are doing amazingly well and that today you just needed to release all those feelings and feel that you aren't the only one who feels like this! I promise you there are lots of us who feel exactly as you do, and all I can say is things do get easier, your past will never be forgotten, but eventually it will be the distant past......it just takes time......keep going and keep sharing. I have discovered this year that writing down how I feel really helps! It feels then like I don't have to hold those thoughts in, that I am allowed to admit my true feelings....even if I don't actually tell someone face to face....my online friends, no a lot more about me and my Cancer, than any of my family. Which suits me fine as the people on here can understand far more than anyone who hasn't walked in our shoes! Hope that made some sense. Sending you a very (((((((((((supportive hug)))))))))) xxxxxx

Posts.Content: Hi daisyjake, WELCOME to the group. I'm sorry you find yourself here but I promise you it's the best place to be, for advice, support and virtual hugs! Now it's time to take a slow deep breath and remind yourself that the CT was clear and that people get headaches for many different reasons and Cancer mets is way down that list! You are feeling anxious and probably not sleeping both of which can cause headaches. It's such a tough time Hun but try not to let your thoughts run wild.  Take things one day at a time. If that's too much then go hour by hour! Try and fill your day with activities that you enjoy. Treat yourself. Even if it's just coffee and cake with a friend. Enjoy it while you can, your taste buds go AWOL while you are on chemo! Sorry to hear you have had to change hospitals, that won't of helped with the anxiety. But try to trust your new team. They are there to help you through this. Ask as many questions as you need to. I always go in with a list as I find my mind goes blank the minute I walk in! You will feel more relaxed once your treatment plan is explained and started. Until then there are loads of lovely ladies and gents on here to help you every step of the way. So take things slowly Hun and try to relax. Worrying won't change anything! Although I know its hard not to! Sending you a ((((((((gentle welcome hug)))))) Sal xxxxx

Posts.Title: Magnesium for hot flushes

Posts.Content: Hi doublefoobie, firstly well done on getting through all that Chemo. Hope you are doing okay!  As for the spotting. It could very well be that your ovaries are kicking back into gear as at your age you won't necessarily of gone through a natural menopause. I was 38 at diagnosis and my periods stopped on my second cycle of FEC! I went on to have one more Fec then 3 of the Tax. A year after my chemo finished my periods returned with a vengeance! Now I wasnt on the herceptin like you as mine was estrogen positive. So I was taking tamoxifen. However any unexplained bleeding should be mentioned to your GP or Oncologist/BCN whoever you have the easiest contact with. They will be able to reassure you that this is normal. It could be that you are going to start getting periods again or it might me the start of menopause. They might want to do a simple ultrasound just to check and see what's going on! So nothing to worry about but in my opinion definitely worth asking one of your health professionals.  My one friendly warning would be, IF your periods do return BE PREPARED they might be a lot heavier than they were! Hopefully that was just my experience, but being forewarned is always best in my opinion. Hope you can get things sorted soon. Take Care. Sal xxx

Posts.Title: How to make GP understand that I'm struggling?

Posts.Content: Thanks Ladies, you've asked some very good questions, just wish I knew the answers! I have bone mets in my sternum and also 2 metal plates which were put in after they removed part of my sternum/ribs in February this year!  I HATE taking painkillers, mainly because the side effects have been awful,but also up to now the pain was 'okay' or at least bearable! But now I have pain in the sternum, which could be the mets although last scan said they were stable (which is great) could be nerves repairing themselves? Or muscle pain?  OR It could be breast pain?? Who knows! It changes from day to day which is why it's difficult to explain to my GP   I am currently on Zoladex injections every 3 weeks! Hormones are clearly all over the place. But I don't feel depressed (like I did on Tamoxifen) This is just pure exhaustion, and pain. I'm sat here now with a throbbing pain in my sternum, like someone is poking me with a red hot poker (obviously I don't know how that feels, but just surmising)!  I'm not sure what needs sorting first, but I think if I can get the pain under control everything else might just fall into place! Or I will at least feel more able to deal with it. I want this Christmas to be enjoyable, I don't another one spoilt by feeling rubbish! Anyway, better get ready to head off to doc's! Will report back later! Thanks for the support, it's very much appreciated xxxx
Posts.Title: How to make GP understand that I'm struggling?

Posts.Content: I have another GP appointment tomorrow. I've been taking painkillers for the last 2 weeks and they have helped a little, but I am still waking every night in pain and have a constant ache throughout the day. Hot flushes have got worse and my sleep is still disrupted, waking every 1.5 to 2hrs throughout the night. I'm exhausted. Last time I saw her she 'listened' while tapping away on her computer. Told me there were a few painkillers I could try, but didn't really seem to understand how much I am struggling. My mood is very up and down at the moment, but on bad days I am really finding it hard to cope. I have spent so long telling everyone I am fine and I can cope, that I can't find a way of explaining how tough I am finding this. I was hoping the pain would of been sorted in the last few weeks, but as I am sat typing this with tears Streaming down my face....I think I can say they haven't sorted anything...yet! I know things take time, but I am just so uncomfortable and scared that this is as good as it gets!!  I begin my new job in January and I want to try and get things sorted before then. But how do I get her to understand?!  Any thoughts gratefully received! Also any ideas on how to cope with bone pain?! I'll try anything  xxx
Posts.Title: How to make GP understand that I'm struggling?

Posts.Content: Hi all, firstly thank you for all the support and advice, I was very touched by all the kind words. I saw the GP and bursting into tears after she asked me how I was, seemed to make her listen! Although embarrassing for me! We chatted for a few minutes about everything, okay it took more than a few minutes! But she listened and this time I mean really listened. She has suggested continuing with the painkillers and also adding another drug at night that will 'hopefully' help with pain control and help me to sleep! She's going to let me try it for a week and if it doesn't help, she'll discuss other options with me. So I am seeing her again next week. The drug she's given me is actually an antidepressant too, so it might help with mood and hot flushes too......which would be a win win if it works! Someone on here mentioned seeing my Oncologist to discuss things. I only saw them a few weeks ago, but sadly didn't see my proper Oncologist but one of his minions...she was very young and just smiled along in all the right places, basically told me everything would improve in time.....thanks.....but not much help! I know a lot of my problems are that I hate to feel I'm being pathetic and not coping! Not helped by everyone around me telling me that I'm 'lucky' that the Cancer has only spread to the one area! Posts.Title: How to make GP understand that I'm struggling?

Posts.Content: Wow Suzie, I hope it helped to get that off of your chest (pardon the pun)! Clearly you are holding a lot of stuff in, so let it out Hun, shout, scream and cry do what you need to do!  THEN Take a deep breath and look at the here and now, try and pin point a few positives in your life......it might take you a while to find some (I know I've been there) but you will. You have a lovely family, who love you for who you are whether you are sweaty Betty or not  its weird that of all the stuff we have been through being hot and sweaty really is the pits, although I think that is mainly down to the fact that we can't see an end to it! I lasted 18 months on tamoxifen and just got lower and lower, it was the Pitts. Starting to struggle on Zoladex, but the difference now is that I am giving myself a break, yes I hate taking tablets, BUT I didn't choose to get breast cancer, so if they are going to give me drugs to keep me alive, I am going to take drugs to make my life worth living! Have you spoken to your GP about this? Or Oncologist? You've tried hard to sort this on your own, now it's time to pull in the reinforcements to help you! This may be the GP, Oncologist or a Counsellor/psychologist! They are all their to help us, but as I have discovered you have to be totally honest with them about how CR*P this is, and I mean really honest!  When I reached breaking point I listed down all my issues and worked through them one at a time with the oncologist and then GP! I am gradually sorting one issue out at a time! Hot flushes are still an issue and getting worse  BUT hopefully I will find a solution for those too at some point! I'm sat writing this with sweat dripping down my face  It's horrid and I feel dirty all the time, but I keep reminding myself, it's not my fault and hopefully things will calm down! But in the mean time I WILL find something that helps me! Because I deserve to be happy! So do you Hun, so please think about trying some medication to help!  I am around and willing to listen, so feel free to message me, anytime! No one is ever alone on this journey, but we all need to be brave and admit that sometimes life after/with Cancer is a real struggle   Sending you the biggest ((((((((hug)))))))) ever xxx

Posts.Title: WHOSE READY FOR A MEET UP??

Posts.Content: Hi CathyPJ, firstly it's great to hear that they can now check nodes during surgery! I had surgery 3 years ago and had to wait 2 weeks after surgery to find out if the nodes contained cancer. Then had to go back for further surgery. So this is definitely a great improvement. Sorry to hear about your mums struggle with Lymphoedema, but just wanted to say that we are all different. I was diagnosed with Lymphoedema and I need to wear a sleeve daily....but in all honesty other than being hot in this weather, it's been okay. I put my sleeve on each morning and don't even think about it. You mention having Radiotherapy to the armpit and yes I believe they can do that. But i also believe that radiotherapy can also increase your risk of Lymphoedema  so I don't think you can assume this will guarantee you won't get it! Sorry! I think you have to make a decision that you are happy with and you can live with. Hopefully your node will be clear  so you won't need either. But I would ask your surgeon what he/she thinks is the best option. It's a tough decision.

Posts.Title: HELP......

Posts.Content: Hi Fiddlecrab, sounds like your unit is really trying to support its younger patients. Wish all hospitals were the same. In my experience what lacks is there ability to see that although we all have the same disease, we are all in very different places in our lives! A lady in her 60's is possibly retired or nearing retirement, so can think about slowing down. A lady who is under 45 and has a young family to look after or works full time has a very different out look.  I found there was always a lot of talk about how well you 'might' do over the next 5/10years.....well at 38 when diagnosed, I was hoping for a lot longer than 5/10 years. So I think they would benefit younger patients by not talking in terms of the next 10 years, instead just talk about the treatment hopefully doing its job. I think more support is needed for young ladies taking hormone therapies. I found absolutely no support when I was seriously struggling with Tamoxifen, I explained at the time that if I was 60/70 I wouldn't mind feeling so rubbish, as I would have the time to rest and relax when needed. But as a 38year old who felt about 90 most days it was hard. I was trying to work while feeling awful. They need to understand that young people still NEED to work, they have to earn a living. I think all hospitals would benefit from realising that living with cancer isn't a Mon-Fri, 9-5 illness. Where's the support and help for those of us who work? Those of us who don't want to use up all our annual leave going to cancer related groups! How about someone think about doing some evening groups or weekends? I'm sure it's not just me who works in a job where I can't just pop out for a few hours to attend a group! Not sure if that's the type of thing your BCN is looking for, but it was good to say it out loud, anyway Xxxxx
Posts.Title: Feedback for BCN

Posts.Content: Hi NikNic, just want to try and calm you slightly! When they told you IF it has spread they can't cure you......that DOESN'T mean you are going to die any time soon! Stage 4 breast cancer, the stage you will be IF it has spread, is still VERY treatable. No you won't ever be cured or Cancer free, but you will hopefully remain on treatments that will keep the cancer under control/stable for many many years!  I don't really want to go into much more detail, because I think it's important that you take things one step at a time. Right now you have Cancer that is curable, until you know any different. There are many ladies on here who have had node involvement that had clear CT scans! So don't assume because it's in the nodes it has to be elsewhere. The nodes are doing their job by trapping the cancer cells. IF however you get the news that it has spread, please come on to the secondaries breast group and you will find lots of us, who are 'living' fairly normal lives. There are ladies who have just started on this journey and others who have been living with Cancer for years and years! So PLEASE don't think this is the end of the world. Because although it is Cr*p and the last thing anyone wants to deal with, there's every chance you will be around for a very long time yet.....and not all treatments make you feel awful and unable to function! So you can still get quality of life too! Allow yourself time to get used to the diagnosis but try not to over think things, take it day by day and deal with things IF and WHEN they happen. But remember you are not alone. We will all be with you every step of the way, if you need us! Now I shall offer you the BIGGEST...... HUG, because I think you could really do with one. Hope that helps a little  Xxxxx

Posts.Title: Why ?

Posts.Content: Firstly Barfy, it sounds to me like you need a Great Big Cuddly....... HUG! I TOTALLY understand that Zombie feeling you talk about! I don't often say this but sometimes I think it helps others to know how low you can get! But reassuring others that MOST people taking Tamoxifen of other hormone therapies do Okay! But I reached desperation point, like you and I would of quite happily of stepped in front of a bus just to end the living hell I was in! EVENTUALLY someone listened and we discussed things! Now onto your situation I would firstly say, have you discussed with the Oncologist how big a difference this drug is having? My cancer was 8/8 on both E and P so I assumed the Tamoxifen was giving me the best chance of staying Cancer free.......but when I spoke to the Oncologist and he put it through the  system, it came back as Tamoxifen giving me an extra 3% protection! Was that enough for me to spend years feeling like that? Well for me no, BUT the decision was taken from me as my secondaries were discovered at the scan results appointment, at which I was going to tell him I was ready to stop the Tamoxifen!  Now, what I can say is........how would I of felt IF I had stopped the tamoxifen 3 months before as I had wanted, then found it had spread? Would I of blamed myself? Would I of hated myself for making the wrong decision? Or would I of thought, well it must of been there before I stopped the drug? What I am saying in a VERY complicated way (sorry) is that YOU are the only one who can decide what to do! It's YOUR body and YOUR life! Picking quality over quantity is a big decision! But it just might be the right one for you! Take your time get as much information as you can and remember even if it did recur it could hopefully still be successfully treated!  One last thing which I'm sure you've heard a thousand times! Have you tried different brands? It does make a difference! Also how about trying Letrozole or another of the hormone drugs? I totally understand if you don't want to try anything else! I hold you find a solution that works for you! But PLEASE talk think through and make an informed decision! Take Care. Sal xxx

It was during Chemo....probably around the first Tax, when I had bone pain from jaw to toes! A couple of friends asked his I was and I told them how awful I felt.....I could see them completely lost for words. Then that annoying reply of "keep your chin up" and I think that was the last time I bothered to share my 'true' feelings. I didn't like hurting other people's feelings, so saying "I'm Fine" was just easier for them to cope with. Maybe we both need to take that leap of faith and see someone to talk about how we are really feeling! Xx

Posts.Title: Have to be honest.....

Posts.Content: magi24, Welcome to the group! Although really sorry you find yourself here.  Now first things first, take some slow deep breaths! Try and relax! Which I know is easier said than done!  I can't help with how long you will have to wait for surgery because all areas are different. But hopefully you have been introduced to a Specialist nurse. She is there to support and answer questions like this, so give her a call on Monday and ask for an approximate time scale! I waited a month from diagnosis to surgery, just to reassure you that 2 weeks isn't that long! Although I know to you it feels like forever! As for the increased pain and headaches! Our bodies and mind plays nasty little tricks on us. Before we find that pesky lump we just get on with the day ignoring any little twinge of pain! HOWEVER as soon as we are diagnosed with Cancer our mind seems to go into overdrive. We notice EVERY little thing going on with our bodies. We also start thinking that every little twinge must be Cancer related! The Cancer must be travelling around the body and growing everyday!  The reality is, all these other issues are completely unrelated to the Cancer! In a physical sense anyway! Your feeling unwell and the headache is likely to be the stress of all this. Totally understandable! But try to relax as much as you can! You might find then that the headaches ease! Remember you probably had headaches before your Cancer diagnosis too! Try and reassure yourself that you are being looked after! They will be doing their best to get you in for surgery ASAP! However I do think calling the Breast Care Nurse and asking for some sort of time scale might just help you to relax a bit. The not knowing is always the worse!  I hope you can begin to relax a little and at least have a break from the headaches for a bit. Keep talking to us on here. We all know how you feel, as we have all been there. Any questions you have just ask! The odds are someone will have an answer for you. Although sometimes we don't need answers we just need to feel listened too and supported. So on that note I shall offer you a Supportive,...... Hope the surgery date comes soon and you can start on the road to recovery! Take Care Hun. Sal xxxx
Posts.Title: Sarcoma breast cancer

Posts.Content: I've signed. Come on ladies and gents. We need to stand together on this. Whether you have been treated, going through treatment or already have secondaries, one day YOU or someone you love, might need this drug! I can't believe we have to fight for a drug that could give people more time, to make special memories with their children and families. It's a horrid world, where someone with money can pay to live longer! Everyone's life is precious, none of us deserved to get cancer, and all of us deserve the best treatment available......whatever it costs! SO PLEASE SIGN, it only takes a few seconds, but it could end up giving others, months or maybe years
Posts.Title: petition the government to continue Kadcyla for breast cancer patients...

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone, I just needed to admit.....probably to myself......that life really is tough sometimes, and I'm allowed to admit I can't cope! Today I was caught off guard, even though my BCN had pre warned me that the oncologist might want to do a biopsy. I had gone assuming he would take a look, say it's just scar tissue and send me on my way! So unlike me to think like that.....usually I prepare for the worse! Anyway the ultrasound of the area was ridiculously painful, you all know how hard they press, well that on top of already being in pain it was horrendous. The lady doing it kept apologising and then said, but we need a good look  Thinking about it now still brings tears to my eyes. I just couldn't cope with the pain and that was before the bloody needle came in to play! i'll spare you anymore details. My BCN was called in just to add to the embarrassment, she was great but I felt so stupid! I suppose I'm just not used to struggling.....but then I'm not used to dealing with so much, while also working and trying to get my life back on track! Anyway, my BCN has booked me in on Wednesday, she's suggested I take more pain relief on that morning, so I will hopefully be slightly more comfortable. I just have to keep reminding myself that it will all be over in 10minutes.....I know I can do it, well I don't have much choice! Now to enjoy the weekend and forget about today's drama. Thanks again for the messages they really do mean a lot.  (((((((((((hugs to you all))))))))))

Posts.Content: Hi Mazza, it's nothing to worry about, in fact it's the one thing I googled when I saw the same on my letter! Except I received this information before I had my diagnosis!  Its basically how likely the lump is to be Cancer, so what they view on the Mammogram was 5 which means almost certainly malignant and the ultrasound the same! If it was M1 or M2 it's not suspicious and unlikely to be cancer! Or at least that's what I found when I looked on Google! Oh and the A3 will be undetermined! In other words they will biopsy the nodes during surgery to see if the nodes are affected! Hope that helps a little! So it's just doctor talk, nothing to worry about! Xxx
Posts.Title: Diagnosis.. what does it mean?

Posts.Content: Thanks chloecat45, I think that's what I find most frustrating, there seems to be no logical reason for the pain. Following sternum surgery I was in severe pain, I certainly wouldn't want to go through that again. But this pain isn't as severe but it's constant, which is hard to live with! I had my last PET CT in Nov and that showed things were stable! So hopefully this is all down to nerve/bone pain, I did have two metal plates put in my sternum and I wonder if that adds to the pain issues?! All stuff I need to discuss with GP or someone more specialised. Thanks for taking the time to reply xxxx
Posts.Title: HELP......

Posts.Content: Well Jillybean, you have come to the right place! This group is full of support, advice and of course lots of....... Hugs! This is a safe place to be open and honest about how you really feel! We all understand that sometimes we can't share our fears with our family and friends because we don't want to upset them. You can share anything you want on here and no one will judge you! I hope you find this site as amazing as I do. I have made some really lovely friends on here, some of them are completely loopy.....me included! But that helps to get us through the tough days! Day or night someone will be here for you! Sal xx
Posts.Title: Recently been diagnosed, looking for support through my journey.

Posts.Content: With you all. I know I have been on here for almost a year now and in that time I have offered support and advice where I could. I try to be as honest as I can and all the advice I give, comes from my own experience. My theory being if I can stop someone else feeling as lonely and bad as I did at times, then me going through it was worth it.  BUT I need to be honest with you all today and admit (not easy for me) that  I had a meltdown today, a big time meltdown! Which is VERY unlike me in fact in the last 3.5years I have never panicked and over reacted like I did today. It was embarrassing and stupid, but at the time it was just all too much for me. I suppose I hit my breaking point!  I have spent all day giving my self a hard time until someone from here text me and listened to me and helped me realise that it's okay to admit that I struggled and that it's nothing to be ashamed of......apparantly emotions make me 'human' So I am admitting very openly that sometimes things do get too much for all of us, but it doesn't mean we have failed, it doesn't mean we have given up, it just means today is a bad day and after getting up and dusting ourselves off (with the help/support of friends) we CAN and WILL succeed next time!  Wednesday will be my 'next time' and hopefully I will be more prepared. At least I know that if I do struggle it's okay, and I don't need to pretend it never happened, while giving myself a hard time! I know I'm my own worse enemy, and I need to give myself the advice I give others  xxxx

Posts.Content: Hi Rach, definitely explain to the person doing the mammogram that you are sore! They are 'usually' very understanding. They have a job to do but they don't want to hurt you.  Also take some painkillers an hour or two before your appointment, I found that helped a lot. Plan something nice to do afterwards, so that this experience is just a small part of your day. As for the emotions of going back to the place you were diagnosed, it's tough. Your emotions will be running high, but take deep breaths and try to relax. It will be all done before you know it!  Sending you a (((((((((supportive hug))))))))) Will be thinking of you tomorrow xxxxxx

Posts.Content: Hi Maxine, can't offer much advice other than to say it was something I suffered with during Chemo and it lasted for around a year afterwards, slowly getting less noticeable day by day! I hope things improve for you too! I know how annoying, painful and frustrating it is ((((((((((((((understanding hug))))))))))))) xxxxx Dreamthief, as you are the fountain of knowledge on most things :-) I wonder if you could answer something for me. Do you know if it's possible for PN to reappear years after Chemo has finished, if the person suffered with it during Chemo? As I said mine sorted itself about a year after chemo finished. But in the last 6 months I have been getting the same issues back again, numb fingertips, sore burning feet or numb feet. Its very frustrating, but more so because no one will say whether it's connected to the chemo or not?! I just get the usual it's not normal but!! Which doesn't help solve the issue! Posts.Title: Tamoxifen (for probably the millionth time)

Posts.Content: Thanks KateJ and Baki, I can speak to my BCN about counselling, except it's not something I can face right now. I struggle with trusting new people, I also struggle to be open about my feelings, when speaking face to face, too many years of smiling and saying all is fine! This is why I find I can off load on here, I can be honest and know that I won't be judged, and even if someone is judging me I can't see them so I will never know  weird I know, but it somehow makes sense to me! I am keeping busy Baki, strangely enough I'm more worried about having the biopsy than getting the results! Although I suppose that might change once I get through the biopsy (okay if I get through the biopsy)! Exeter is a beautiful city, after spending years in London I now realise how much I love my home city  Spent today with my nieces, I'm exhausted, but had an amazing time, once we got over the mini drama of my youngest niece asking me if I was going to die soon  Something was said at school and bless her heart she was so upset! I'll have a rant about it later! Anyway sending you both a ((((((((hug))))))) Baki I am touched that with all you are going through you have taken the time to write such a considerate reply! This is why you are worth every penny those cancer drugs cost  xxxxx

Do you know if they typically tell you the results whilst you're there or do you have to go back for them?  Hi Rach, this will very much depend on your hospital. Posts.Title: CT vs Bone Scan

Posts.Content: Hi Elaine, it is standard practise to do a CT scan as a follow up to hotspots on the bone scan! They will be checking the areas that lit up on the bone scan and checking that everything else is clear. It's a horrid time I know, as I went through the same in Nov 15!  Hopefully once they have that information they will know what's going on and you will have an action plan put in place! Sending you a (((((((((hug))))))))) xxx

Posts.Title: Happy Sunday.

Posts.Content: My CT confirmed that the area on my sternum was 'possibly' cancer! But was otherwise clear! Then I had an MRI to check the area again at which point they decided to operate to see if they could remove the whole area, which in theory would put me at NED again! Sadly they didn't get it all. But that's life. It's been a year now and I'm feeling okay about things! Still have 'off' days, but on the whole I'm pretty positive about things. In fact the down days are usually down to the hospital or GP visits  xxxx
Posts.Title: Still the waiting game

Posts.Content: Hi kargus, I think I can safely say that NOBODY on this site will say "it's just a tablet" we all know it can be a life changing tablet. I have major panics about when I might have to start on these drugs! My time on Tamoxifen was horrendous. I'm currently on the Zoladex and although that has side effects they have been bearable, although the last few weeks have been rough! I bet the lack of the brand you require is down to cost, everything is down to cost! Although I don't think it helps that Oncologists and GP's seem reluctant to admit that different brands can cause different side effects! I know when I first said that to my oncologist she gave me 'that look'!! Not sure there's much you can do, others than search your local pharmacys and see if you can get some sourced, you shouldn't have to do this, but that's just how things are, I'm afraid. I hope you are able to get this sorted, or you find another brand/tablet that suits you better! I wish these drug companies/health authorities would realise how awful these side affects can be! I wish they could live in our shoes for just one day, in fact in my current state they wouldn't last more than a few hours Sending you a ((((((((((supportive hug))))))))) not much help, but just to let you know you are not alone xxxxxx
Posts.Title: supply of letrozole

Posts.Content: Susie39 Welcome to the group. Sorry you find yourself here, but you have certainly come to the right place for advice and more importantly support!  I don’t think it matters how early your Cancer was caught, or how big/small the tumour is. It’s still Cancer and it’s popped up in your life uninvited and very unwelcome! Feeling scared is totally understandable, this disease has taken away your peace of mind! It’s made you question life and it’s made you think about your mortality, we have all been there Hun and let’s face it it’s a pretty shitty place to be!  So let’s try and reassure you and give you a helping hand out of that quick sand that you are probably currently stood in! Breast Cancer is VERY treatable especially when it is caught early! The surgery is very straight forward and usually done as a day case! Once you have had your surgery your mind will be a little clearer because the Cancer will be gone, the radiotherapy is used to ‘mop up’ any minute cells that might of been there! It’s the ‘belt and braces’ of treatment!  If you are finding yourself really worried and unable to sleep or think straight during the day. It might be worth seeing your GP for something to calm you down. But sometimes coming on here and talking about your fears is enough to help clear your head! If there is anything you want to ask then ask away. Day or night there is usually someone around who will be able to answer your questions and don’t think that any question is a ‘silly question’ I promise you we have all asked what seems like silly question at times!  Well I think I have probably gabbled on enough! So I shall leave you in peace! But please remember we are all here to help you in any way we can! So don’t feel you have to do this alone because you don’t! We will be here every step of the way! Sal xx

Posts.Title: Oncologist follow up appointment

Posts.Content: Hi Debs, my advice is to write down EVERYTHING that is bothering you! I mean EVERYTHING! Even the small things that might or might not be directly related to the treatment. Also ask ask about things to look out for, to be aware of. I found my biggest issue was finding a small change in my breast/breast area and then spending days debating whether I needed to mention it to someone or not! It really does start driving you loopy!  Hope the appointment goes well and you get out of it, what you need. Sending you a special ((((((((((Rainbow Hug))))))))) xxxx
Posts.Title: Oncologist follow up appointment

Posts.Content: my heart strings were well and truly tugged I was meeting up with my sister and nieces. I was greeted with my usual hug and kiss, but the youngest whose 10, hugged me and whispered I don't want you too die, and burst into tears! Apparantly some of the children at school were discussing cancer, they were doing a lesson on local charity's, anyway my niece mentioned that I had Cancer and she was told I was going to die soon, because everyone with Cancer dies We had a long long chat about the cancer I have and how it's treatable and that I hope to be around for a long time, but that sometimes people do die of cancer, but usually after they have been very ill for a while. Just wanted her to know the truth, well as near to the truth as I could.  We then went on to have a lovely day. But on my way home I couldn't hold back the tears, I was so sad that she had had to hear that and how upset it had made her. I was just glad that she asked me and didn't just bottle it up (don't want her to be like her auntie in that respect)! It made me think afterwards how feared Cancer is and that even after all the advances in treatment children are still growing up thinking that Cancer is a death sentence. My sister suggested if I feel up to it I could go in to her school and chat to the children about 'living with cancer'! I'm not sure I can face it right now, but I think I should try, as I do think it's important that we try and show youngsters that being diagnosed particularly with breast cancer, isn't the end of the world! Although it feels like it when you are going through it. Maybe if we talked about these things more openly the children who are around us will possibly grow up with less fear, maybe they will not have the fear we all had when we found that lump, maybe they wouldn't put off seeing the GP, maybe they would in turn teach their children not to fear the disease!  Or will Cancer always be the thing we fear more than anything else?
Posts.Title: Today......

Posts.Content: Julia I'm pleased that your daughters school were supportive, I'm sure your daughter will grow up to have a completely different view on Cancer, having seen you come through it!  I totally understand the fear that surrounds any illness, but I think it's a shame that all the work that has gone in to treating cancer, to help people live longer or be cured, hasn't gone on to take SOME of the fear away!  I know we all get our fears from what we see and hear as we are growing up. BUT times are changing, more people are surviving Cancer and many people live long term with the disease. The more I think about it the more I think, children deserve to hear more about Cancer, than just, it kills you! Maybe if we can show children how far treatments have come they in turn will pass on this thinking to their children. Maybe just maybe in 20/30 years time, we will have a cure for all cancers, but if not the children will at least be growing up in a world where Cancer can be said  the way we say, diabetes or asthma or any other long term illness! Maybe just maybe the BIG C will be a distant memory  We can but hope! Xxxx
Posts.Title: Today......

Posts.Content: Hi Hun, welcome to the club that none of us wanted to join, I'd say I hope your stay is short, but I think you would prefer honest opinions! My opinion is they seem pretty sure it's Cancer, sorry! I just wish they had said that too you rather than leave you with more questions than answers. The biopsy results will tell them if it is definitely cancer and if so what type! The scans will give them a clearer picture of everything, so they have all the information they need. I know it is all happening very fast which must be very daunting, but it's better than waiting around for weeks for everything to get moving! One thing to bear in mind is, IF it does turn out to be Breast Cancer, it is VERY treatable! So don't panic! You have come to the right place, we will all be here to help, support, advise and offer (((((((((supportive hugs)))))))) but most importantly, day and night there is always someone here to talk to I hope that has helped a little, I apologise if it's not what you wanted to hear  But from my own experience I do think that sometimes they are 'fairly' sure something is cancer before they get the official biopsy results.  I hope you have a supportive family or group of friends, because they will all help you through whatever lies ahead, as will we! Sending you (((((((((a welcome hug)))))))) xxx

Good Luck  and as he reminded me, there is nothing to feel guilty about, you have paid into the system for years, the idea being money is there if you are unfortunate enough to need it. So don't feel guilty.  I am hoping I won't need to claim anything....but if I can't get a job soon I will have to! But he has at least reassured me, that I am entitled to it as I have been paying into it for years! Xx
Posts.Title: Giving up work

Posts.Content: Hi Bramblefarm, Welcome to the Community, although sorry you find yourself here. I think the honest answer is, until they remove the lump they won't know for sure.....unless....they have already found thae cancer has spread to your lymph nodes under your arm, or if the biopsy has come back as triple negative or her+ in which case Chemo is a definite! Sorry if that doesn't help much! You know I had long hair and dreaded the thought of losing it, it had been long for over 20years. Now I have it shoulder length and I prefer it like this! Also remember you could use the cold cap! There are options! But the most important thing is to get rid of the cancer! I know it's scary, but you are not alone Hun, we are all here for you! By this time tomorrow you will of had lots of welcome messages, we are a VERY friendly bunch. All on different stages of this journey, but all very caring and supportive of each other. I should now be sleeping so I shall say goodnight and just finish by offering you a Welcome....... Hug. It's a long, tough journey Hun. But you WILL get through it. Just take it one step at a time. Sal xxxxx
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Grade 3

Posts.Content: Hi Optimistic, I tend to agree with Helen (mistymoley) There's no point wasting the time you have been given, constantly wondering if the treatment is working or not! The best thing you can do is live every day to the Full, keep an eye out for changes in your body, but don't over think things......yes I know it's easier said than done!  As for you beind ER6 I am ER8/8 and PR/8/8 BUT sadly Tamoxifen didn't work for me! Now I don't say this to worry you, I say this to point out that what ever our ER score there are no guarantees! A lot will depend on your origional diagnosis, lymph involvement and treatment. None of us know how we will react to any drug, hut worrying about it won't help. Please try and calm down, you are a lovely lady and I have spoken to you a lot over the months. You have a beautiful family who want/need their mum! Please don't take the next few years away from them worrying about something that may never happen! Live in the moment......which right now is that you are NED, that is good.......really good! Please enjoy it! You went through hell to get to this point, now it's time to TRY and find a way to move forward. To do that you can't keep thinking the worse! (((((((((((((((((BIG HUGS))))))))))))))) Hun! We all care about you and it's horrible watching you worry so much! Sal xxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Er 6

Posts.Content: Hi Bluebell22 what a horrible situation to be in. However it really is good that they are checking things out properly. There really isn't any point taking any possible remnants of cancer away if it kills you during the process!!  IF they can't operate or have to delay it would they offer Radiotherapy? As this is another way of them killing off any stray cells that the chemo 'might' of missed! Although it sounds like the chemo has done a great job! Try not to let it worry you too much. Sadly this is out of your control. They will collect all the evidence and make an informed decision, with your best interests at heart.  I do know how frustrating it is when the plan set in place is suddenly turned upside down. But I think it's one lesson I learnt very early on. There are no guarantees with this cancer journey!! Take things one day at a time and expect the unexpected!! Good Luck Hun, I really hope they have a revised plan that you feel happy with soon. Sending you a (((((((gentle hug))))))))) Sal xx
Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: Hi Pompompom, sorry you find yourself here. But Welcome to the group! Was your Mother in Law not told the stage?  I'm afraid once it has spread past the breast/lymph nodes it's is classed as stage 4! Which is treatable but no longer curable. Depending on the type of breast cancer your Ma in law has, there are many treatment options available. People can live a long time with stage 4 disease, particularly those with it confined to just the bones! Hope this helps and wishing you and your Ma in Law all the best. If you or she has anymore questions or just needs a place to off load. We are a nice bunch and are all here to listen and help if we can! Sal xxx

Posts.Title: Hello and thank you for being there

Posts.Content: Hi elaineo2 sorry to hear you are having a worrying time, but wanted to reassure you that it is possible to have pain years after surgery/radiotherapy! I am 3 years on and I still have pain in breast and under arm. It's down to the scar tissue and nerves....oh and for me lack of eostrogen. Please don't panic it might not be anything sinister, but good to get it checked out xxx
Posts.Title: Breast and arm pain

Posts.Content: Hi NiceCuppa, how are you feeling this morning? I think the simple answer is NO it shouldn’t be this painful! Yes the injection is uncomfortable and yes it might hurt quite a bit but the pain should die down almost immediately! As for the bleeding, if the nurse has nicked a vein, that can cause a fair bit of bleeding which would of been made worse by the blood thinning drugs you are on! If you are still feeling rough today I would go and get checked out. I am obviously no doctor but I have been having these injections for the last 3years every 3wks so I feel I am experienced enough to say that this isn’t the norm! You can get a cream that will numb the area before you have the injection! I have never bothered as my nurse has been great and my injections only hurt for a split second! A couple have stung a bit and one did cause a rather large bruise!! But on the whole it’s fine! So please don’t be put off after this one bad experience! It could be the nurse hasn’t done many of these injections and hasn’t done it quite as well as someone whose more experienced. But like I said if you are still feeling rough, please get checked out! Sal xxxx
