Posts.Title: Breast clinic (mammogram )

Posts.Content: So as I sit here absolutely fuming, I thought I would share my disbelief  at the email I just received from my BCN, bearing in mind I only spoke to her yesterday and she said she would call me with results tomorrow (Friday)! this is the email I received, clearly written as she finished for the day! As I replied immediately and the usual out of office email, bounced back! Hi,  No answer on scan as yet, I am not in tomorrow so will chase on Monday morning I am having trouble getting you into clinic on the 6th as no doctors. I can always give you the heads up on the results and get you in the week after and that will allow me to put it through the MDT if I need to. I hope that sounds okay to you. Sorry for messing you about I have tried for the 6th but I think the week after would potentially work better.  Thanks ............ So none of this was said when I met her face to face yesterday! Seriously why tell someone you will be in touch with results, when you know you won't? Do my feelings really account for nothing, with the one person who is 'supposed' to be supporting me through this? Waiting for results is bad enough, without them building up your hopes and basically telling you a pack of lies! I have had enough  she knew I needed these results so I could make decisions about my future. But they just don't care! They are there to treat the Cancer, but hey I'M A PERSON, WITH FEELINGS.......NOT JUST A NUMBER ON A COMPUTER! SERIOUSLY FED UP! Apologies for moaning AGAIN

Posts.Title: Picc line for chemo

Posts.Content: WORRIED2016, you are a little ahead of yourself, most of us hit this period of uncertainty when we leave the hospital after the last Radiotherapy appointment! You are a week early It's PERFECTLY NORMAL and it's something you have to go through, so you can start to make sense of everything you have just been through. It's also the point that you 'might' start grieving the life you have lost. That life you had when you weren't WORRIED about every little ache and pain, in fact you probably ignored them like we all did!  If you are near a Maggies Centre they do a great course about moving on once the main treatment is done! I think they do an online one too! Tamoxifen will hopefully keep the cancer away and you will be feeling physically better in a few months once the radiotherapy effects have worn off. Once you are back into the swing of life without constant hospital visits things will hopefully settle. But don't expect too much too soon, you have been through a lot.  Good Luck with the rest of your Radiotherapy. Remember if you are ever worried about anything, we are all here to listen and advise and so are your BCN and Oncologist. It might feel like you are being let loose to go it alone, but you aren't! (((((((((((Reassuring Hug))))))))))) xxxxx
Posts.Title: Silly worries? How do you sort your head out

Posts.Content: Hi all, I just wanted to see if anyone else has had issues with Hormone therapies? I was on Tamoxifen for 18months and struggled. I had every side effect  imaginable but the worse was the VERY low mood, which improved after just 2 weeks off of the drug. I am now on Zoladex injections every 3 weeks. In the last month I have noticed I am getting that very low mood AGAIN  I am also struggling with memory. I struggle to concentrate and have moments when watching tv, where I just 'zone out'. I also struggle to think of certain words!! It's really starting to get to me, especially as I know this treatment is long term.  Starting to think my body REALLY needs Estrogen........even if it's trying to kill me! HELP!

Posts.Title: Hormone Therapies, Mood and Memory.....

Posts.Content: Totally understand Hun, sadly I think part of that comes down to the whole PINK and FLUFFY brigade, who have somehow made Breast Cancer, out to be the 'best' cancer to have! That its EASILY treated and EVERYONE goes back to their OLD life after a year!! Hmmmmmm I don't think it's quite that easy! But if its what people see and hear in the media then that's what they are going to think! You look NORMAL so surely you are fine again! I have to tell you it's no easier when you are living with Secondary Breast Cancer! Once you tell people it's stable, they seem to hear, EVERYTHING IS FINE, because they assume stable means CURED or no more treatment! They don't seem to notice that its ongoing treatment as is Primary breast cancer if you are on hormone therapy! Somehow we need to re educate people and explain that just because the Chemo, Surgery and Radiotherapy is done, it doesn't mean life is back to normal! However much we wish it was! Sending you an understanding (((((((((HUG)))))))) Sal xx
Posts.Title: Annoyed!!!!!

Posts.Content: So tomorrow I have an appointment at the local hospital that I am transferring too. Having spoken to the GP she said its normal protocol to meet the Breast Surgeon first, who will then refer me to the Oncologist! So more appointments to come! So any thoughts on what I should expect from this appointment? The letter sent was a standard letter which is sent to anyone seeing the breast surgeon for the first time, telling you tests and scans may take up to 4hrs etc etc! Now I had a mammogram in June and recently had an ultrasound of my treated breast. Now obviously they won't have access to these until they request them from my old hospital (nothing's ever simple)! So I am going to take the letters I have that are copies of what is sent to the GP, I also have the latest scan report, which I can take! But even with all this do you think they might want to do their own mammogram/ultrasound? Or maybe just wait for the resent scans to be sent to them? I want to prepare myself as I've only just started getting this pain under control and the last thing I need is a mammogram or ultrasound.  I know all hospitals are different, so really just want an idea of what might happen, if anyone else has experienced changing hospitals?!  It's funny, however long you are on this Cancer journey and however well you think you are doing, as soon as there is a hospital appointment due, that underlying panic begins Although I am going to give myself a pat on the back as I have known about this appointment for over a week and I am only starting to worry now....the day before! Which is good for me  xxx

Posts.Title: Appointment at New Hospital...

Posts.Content: Hi Andrea55, i was diagnosed with Lymphoedema of the arm and breast, like you I was hoping to dodge that bullet. There are a few useful videos online showing you how to do a gentle massage that helps the lymph flow, there are also a few simple exercises that help the lymph fluid flow!  I have been wearing a sleeve for must be 18months, and I must say...although it's not the height of fashion, it really doesn't bother me anymore. Yes it's a bit hot in summer, but typically it's the hot weather that you mainly need it. I put it on each morning just like it's another item of clothing. Nobody really takes any notice now! When I first had it I had to get used to people asking what I had done to my arm, then in turn look at their blank faces when I said I had Lymphoedema!! I think the most frustrating thing for me is that the sleeve is a constant reminder of Breast Cancer, but it's certainly not as bad as I feared. You just need to make sure you look after the arm, don't over use it and keep an eye on any cuts, scratches or insect bites! Wishing you all the best xx
Posts.Title: Lymphodema in arm

Posts.Content: Hi Andrea, definitely not ;-) if you enjoy holidays in the sun, then go for it! I went to Florida just before an official diagnosis of Lymphoedema! Swimming really helped with the swelling! I was super cautious with using an insect repellant, as you really want to try and avoid insect bites. Also some doctors recommend taking a prescription for antibiotics with you, just in case you get bites or cuts and they start looking infected! Not something I've had to deal with yet...thank goodness. I saw a Lymphoedema nurse who is connected to my hospital. Luckily my arm wasn't too bad, so I didn't need the MLD, but still did show me how to do it.  My sleeve seems to be doing its job, even managed to go down a size, so that was progress. It's frustrating and at times depressing, but it's bearable. Sadly it's the hand we've been dealt and we have to live with it!  Good Luck with it xxx
Posts.Title: Lymphodema in arm

Posts.Content: Hi DnA, sorry you and your wife are having to deal with this. All I can say is keeping busy is the only thing you can do to try and keep your mind active and away from negative thoughts. As for looking online Dr Google is NOT the place to look. Not right now while you don't fully know what you are looking at. I'd just like to say to you both that what ever the diagnosis Breast Cancer is treatable, even IF and its a big IF it has spread further, it is still very Treatable. I was diagnosed in 2013, Secobdaries in 2016 and I am still here, feeling okay. Working 3 days a week and very much living with Cancer. It's not easy and some days are better than others. But if you have a good support network and you take things one step at a time, you will be fine? Sending a  Hug, to you and your wife. I hope the news on Thursday and a treatment plan helps for you to feel you have regained some control. Love to you both. Sal xx

Posts.Title: Breast cancer hopes and fears.

Posts.Content: Hi Moolia, sounds like you have been through a lot in a very short time space. Although it also sounds like you are coping really well, so well done you The CT is routine after finding cancer in the nodes, but definitly doesn't mean it's spread as the nodes are there to catch these little blighters and that's exactly what yours have hopefully done. IF any have sneaked past the Chemo will mop them up! Your emotions will be all over the place, I'm sure. Some days you feel okay and other days you are thinking very dark thoughts. But sounds like you caught things early which hopefully gives you a very good chance of kicking cancers butt! There are lots of people on here who can offer lots of advice and virtual hugs! There's a Chemo group, who share how they are getting on and help support each other. Chemo is tough but very much doable. Any questions you have just ask as someone will know the answer. If you need to rant do it, if you need a moan feel free or if you just need somewhere to share your inner most thoughts, we are all here to listen and truly understand how you feel. So I'll stop rambling on and just offer you a (((((((((((welcome hug)))))))))) xxx

Posts.Title: 2hrs Sleep....

Posts.Content: I'd like to say that all people are like this.....but sadly that isn't so. I work as a Nanny and sadly nannies aren't supposed to get sick, we are superhuman you know I will always do my best to arrange appointments around my employers work schedules, but obviously that's not always possible! In my last position during treatment, I was organising play dates, so that the children would be collected by friends,....just in case I couldn't be there in time! I didn't want to let my bosses down. But the reality is that just made life more stressful and me unhappy!  So this time I want to try and be more organised, so that my bosses and I can work together........I have to constantly remind myself that EVERYONE gets sick and in any other job, you would be entitled to time off for medical appointments. I am more than happy to take it as leave, but was really touched that she just said, don't worry about it  xxx

Posts.Title: Anyone in Exeter?

Posts.Content: Hi Alison, I had joint pain with Tamoxifen and also foot pain....but the foot pain started during Chemo and didn't completely disappear until 6 months into tamoxifen! So I would assume for me that was chemo side effects! I found moisturising my feet at night with lots of lotion then putting socks on top and leaving over night helped! I also wore two pairs of socks during the day, which helped! As for knee pain I used an ibuprofen cream, which helped! That and lots of hot baths in the evenings! But if it goes on for a few weeks definitly mention it to your GP! We can't blame everything on Tamoxifen or Cancer! Xxxx
Posts.Title: Feet and knees!

Posts.Content: Now I don't want to speak too soon, or jinx things! But as most of you know I start my new job tomorrow.  Well I had a mini meltdown this morning as I looked through the post that I had left on the side and found I had received an appointment through for my first appointment with my new Oncologist! It's on the 17th Jan! Now luckily it's a 9am appointment and the hospital is very near where I work! Now assuming things run to time (miracles sometimes happen) I should be able to get to work just a little bit late....I start at 10, so in the perfect world I might even be on time!  But as I wanted to start out on the right foot, I decided I should contact my boss and let her know about the appointment and offer to work later if it was okay for me to come in a little later that day....or Offer to take it as annual leave! I had a little cry (silly I know) as I just had visions of this being exactly like last time Once I had calmed down and sorted myself out I called her........she listened to what I said and said "no problem I'm not going away that week so I will be here, so come over as soon as you are finished, no need to work later or take time off"!! I just thanked her, said see you tomorrow and then came off the phone and burst into tears!  I think I've found my perfect job, with a kind and understanding family. Could 2017 really be the year I get some sort of 'normal' life back  I hope so, I really do! Xxxx

Posts.Title: ONLINE PARTY......

Posts.Content: Hi Hun, that feeling will pass. It just takes time. I think it's at times like this that we allow ourselves to think about what we have been through. Just going back to the hospital brings back a lot of memories that we 'think' we have dealt with, but the truth is while going through everything, we didn't have time to process anything. So for some of us it's weeks, months or even years before we really stop and see what we have just been through. I know for me, when I went back to the same clinic for my annual mammogram I was overcome with emotion. Suddenly I was back to where this whole nightmare had begun. I could remember how nervous I was on that day, how I sat telling myself it would be fine, I would be okay! After going through diagnosis, Surgery x2, chemo and radiotherapy with virtually no tears. The day I left that clinic after just a simple annual mammogram, I was in pieces! All those tears that I had unknowingly been keeping locked away inside suddenly gushed out!  BUT... Those feelings soon passed, each day I felt a little better about things, I slowly processed things and eventually stopped thinking about them as I was too busy trying to get on with life! However, every time I have gone back for annual mammograms I am taken right back to those feelings, the what ifs come back with a vengeance! But I think that's only natural. So what you are feeling will pass, it's perfectly normal and just takes time. So be kind to yourself, allow yourself to process everything at a speed to suit you. Most of us have been there and totally understand. May I offer you a ((((((((supportive hug))))))))) Hope you managed to get some sleep and hopefully tomorrow will be a slightly calmer day xxxxxxx

Posts.Content: toxophilite PS Constipation - have you tried (if you can) very large doses of Vit C? Increase the dose till you get diarohea, then reduce it slightly. 8000mg a day for me when on steroids. Haven't tried that, my problem is I don't go for anything up to 7/8/9 days, then I get major stomach cramps and the explosive diarreah! Posts.Title: Feeling in control...........

Posts.Content: Like you have already said, it's a decision that only you can make.  But I just wanted to say, there are no guarantees in this world...sadly! I went through surgery x2, Chemo, Radiotherapy and Hormone Therapy. So in theory giving myself the best possible chance of beating this disease. 18months after the end of all the treatment, I was diagnosed with secondary cancer to the Bone. I know I did everything I was told to give myself the best chance, and it still came back. Mine had spread to lymph nodes, so different to you. I think you have to decide if you can live with the 'what ifs' if you don't have Chemo and it comes back! Will you see yourself as one of the unlucky ones, or will you blame yourself for not having the Chemo?!  There is no right or wrong answer in this. It's finding the answer you can live with. I think if you're genuinely not sure the Oncotype DX test could give you a more informed decision! Whatever you decide I wish you all the best. Take Care xxx

Posts.Title: arm bandaging for lympodema

Posts.Content: For the first time in 3.5years! After a restless night, with my head going round and round in circles I decided to email my BCN before I left for work, if nothing else it would hopefully clear my head and I would be able to see how contactable she is! Well I returned home to a reply! I was VERY impressed. Not only did she reply to my message, she had already spoken to the Oncologist and checked out a mammogram appointment for me! I was and still am grinning from ear to ear My email was to tell her that I was struggling with the thought of starting any new treatments at the moment, having just started work and on the whole feeling human, albeit knackered! Yes I have pain issues, sleep issues and toilet issues. But all of the treatments on offer would add to these (possibly) not help them.  So I asked if it would be possible to stick with being scanned regularly and IF and when something changed, like the Cancer woke from its nap, could I start on the treatments then? Or in a few months if I felt I was ready to start at some point. She replied to say that was fine, oncologist said they were all treatment options, available to me if I wanted them, well not want, but you know what I mean. The fact I felt a weight had been lifted when I read this email, told me that I am just NOT ready to have anymore treatment at this time. My view is, the mets are contained in the one place, they are currently napping and hopefully will stay that way while I'm on the Zoladex. Even if they wake up in the next year or next few months, at least I will of had time to get used to the idea, I would of had a few months (hopefully longer) of feeling in control again. Of feeling that cancer was on the back burner for a while! I don't know if this is the correct decision, but it's the right one for me at this moment in time. If I had a crystal ball, maybe my decision would be easier, but as I haven't I will make do with going with my gut feeling, which is that I finally feel someone is listening to me, and that is worth a huge amount.......I Think moving hospitals could really be the kick I needed to stand up for myself, it is MY life after all  xxx
Posts.Title: Feeling in control...........

Posts.Content: Hi Londonmumof2  I was diagnosed almost 6 years ago and was living in London at the time. I found a lovely shop called Trendco who you will find at 64 Westbourne Grove, London. It’s just off of Nottinghill. The staff in there at the time were amazing. I had booked an appointment and the lady I saw was kind and patient, nothing was too much trouble.  I believe they even run support groups for people who are dealing with hair loss for whatever reason. They had a great selection of wigs and were full of advice. So might be worth a look. But like I said it was 6years ago that I used them!  Just one other thought, you might want to check with your Oncologist about swimming in a public pool while on Chemo! I know I recall mine saying best to avoid them especially on the week that your immune system will be at its lowest! But maybe the current view is different!  Hope that helps and good luck with the wig fitting and your upcoming treatment. Take Care. Sal xxx

Posts.Title: BRCA test results

Posts.Content: Hi Peggysgirl, Welcome to the forum. Sorry you find yourself here but you have definitely come to the right place for support and advice. No need to apologise for 'offloading', as that's exactly what this site is for. There is nothing you can say that won't of been said before by numerous other people! We have all been where you are, the worry, the fear and the feeling of isolation as it feels like no one understands. But we do Hun, we really do! The Lymph nodes are there to hopefully stop the cancer cells from spreading to other parts of the body, so try not to panic. Many ladies have positive lymph nodes like you but go on to find the rest of the nodes and the scans are clear!  At the moment concentrate on what you do know, which is that you face more surgery to get the clear margins. Not what anyone wants to hear, but you can do it Hun. No you don't have to be 'brave' none of us are brave, we are just coping the best way we can, after all, what choice do we have?!  If you want to cry, cry! If you need to shout and get angry do! This journey will be full of emotions. You will have up and down days throughout. But the one thing I can guarantee you, is that you are not alone. There will always be someone here to offer you advice, support or just a shoulder to lean on! We share tears, we share laughter and we definitely share hope! Things have come a long way since your mum sadly passed away. So please don't lose hope. There are many treatment options available. We are all here to help you through each stage! So I think I have babbled on enough, especially as I should be sleeping! But that shows there is always someone around, day of night  I hope this helps a little and if nothing else, reassures you that you are not alone and that how you are feeling is perfectly normal! I am sending you a (((((((((supportive welcome hug)))))))))  Look forward to getting to know you more xxxxxx
Posts.Title: I'm so scared

Posts.Content: Baki,  Cancer sucks and what you are going through really sucks......that's putting it politely. BUT you are worth every penny that is being spent on treating you! It's very very frustrating that these drugs are only available at a cost, but that's another issue. You need to turn things around, these drugs will hopefully buy you more time......but instead of worrying about the cost and wasting money....as you put it......how about doing some special things to make special memories that you can leave behind for your family and friends! I know if you were my mum or sister I would give every penny I have if it meant I had more time with you! Money can't buy special memories which will last forever. I'm sure your family would rather have weeks/months or years with you, than a pile of money! It's now just you that has to realise you are worth this, you deserve to be with your family as long as you can, but you also need to use the time wisely. I know it must be hard, but make the most of this time, enjoy every minute that you can, show your family how much they mean to you, you might not leave them money, but in years to come they will be able to look back and remember the time and effort you put in to making special memories for them!  Your love for them, and them for you is worth more than any amount of money!  You're entitled to hate all those things except yourself......BECAUSE YOU HAVE NOT DONE ANYTHING WRONG.....YOU DID NOT CHOOSE TO HAVE CANCER......YOU CAN'T CONTROL WHAT HAPPENS.......BUT YOU CAN MAKE THE MOST OF THE TIME YOU HAVE.......BECAUSE YOU ARE A WONDERFUL LOVING AND CARING PERSON WITH A BEAUTIFUL HEART. You have helped me so much in the last year, you don't deserve any of this, none of us do. But if you still want to fight, don't let the cost stop you! Sending you a ((((((((((heartfelt hug)))))))))) xxxxxxxx

Posts.Content: Hi Ludo, firstly CONGRATULATIONS on the great news and for getting through the surgery! Will you be having any Radiotherapy or Hormone Therapy like Tamoxifen? I only ask because if your Cancer was Hormone Positive, then Tamoxifen or one of the other drugs, if you are post menopausal would offer better protection against a recurrence than Chemo would! If I was in your shoes I would be really pleased that I had dodged the Chemo bullet. I certainly don't think I would put my body through it unless my doctors thought it was really needed! I'm not really sure why this has been left as your decision? Surely your surgeon/oncologist has decided whether or not it is required? Obviously only you know what is right for you, but as someone who is still living with the side effects of chemo 4 years on, I would say IF you don't need it! Count your lucky stars and start getting on with your life again! I know it's hard and scary, but you will get there! It just takes time. Sending you a (((((((((((Supportive Hug))))))))))) xxxxxx
Posts.Title: ALL CLEAR RESULT !! Still have a dilema ?!?!

Posts.Content: Optimistic I presume because it was in 2 nodes it means a higher risk of tiny cells lying dormant. No I haven't spoke to anyone but am lucky to have a lovely hubby and children  Hi, sadly there are no guarantees in all this. There are people with no node involvement who go on to have a secondary diagnosis and some people with lots of nodes involved who go on for many many years with NED. All you can do is have the treatment that is on offer and live your life knowing that whatever happens in the future, you gave yourself the best chance. He's not saying it won't work, he's just giving you the information, although when you are already feeling low, it's the last thing you need to hear. But I suppose you have to question how you would feel if he led you to believe the chemo would cure you and in a year or two it returned?! I've been there Hun, and it's not a good place to be! I think honesty is the best policy in all this.....although there are ways to say things and maybe that's what he needs to work on! Sending you a ((((((((hug))))))) xx
Posts.Title: Any advice

Posts.Content: This picture says it all........ I have gone from someone who takes absolutely no medication for anything to someone who is taking 20+ tablets a day, just to get through the day! Which would be okay with me, IF they were solving all my problems. But they haven't and worse than that I am having to do my own research to discover different things about the drugs! Some of the 'issues' I mentioned to the hospice nurse and Oncologist 'COULD' be related to one of the pain meds and yet neither of them mentioned this. Instead the hospice nurse suggested changing to a stronger med in the same family of drugs and the Oncologist asked about my 'issues' and then brushed them neatly under the table! What is the point of having these drugs and lists of side effects, if medical staff aren't willing to to listen to the patient when they mention the problems they are having?! Sorry just need to get that off my chest! Rant over! Wishing everyone a lovely day xxxxx

Posts.Content: Oh Batfinkcaz, I only just saw this and felt so sad for you. I know how hard it is to be surrounded by people who are getting on with their lives without a care in the world. When you feel like you are carrying a time bomb round with you.  I can't stop you feeling like this but I can tell you that you WON'T feel like this forever. It takes time but eventually you will put this behind you, you will never forget and there will be appointments and anniversaries that bring back these thoughts. But you will be happy again and you will be the life and soul of the party again! Just not this time!  Allow yourself time to grieve for the life you had, then you will start to embrace the life you have now. It's not easy and believe me it can take a long time. But one day you will wake up and not think about Cancer for a whole morning! Then for a whole day! Then without realising it you will go for a few days without letting it be in your every thought! It might not feel like it now. But 2018 is the year you will get your life back, because 2017 was the year you went through hell to kick Cancers Butt!  Wishing you a great 2018, I hope it brings lots of fun and laughter to you and your family. Sal xx

Posts.Title: Should I go and see GP or mention to BCN?

Posts.Content: Hi TootsBess, well done on getting to the half way point  The Tax part, like the EC varies from person to person. But main side effects are aching muscles and bones! I had pain from my jaw to my toes which came as a bit of a shock as I had breezed through FEC. But on my 2nd dose I was prepared and given better pain relief and so it was easier. Also tastebuds totally dissapeared, nothing tasted nice.....not even chocolate!!! But it returned not long after treatment ended I also suffered with tingling/loss of feeling in fingers and very sore feet, but again it sorted itself out eventually after the chemo finished. But any issues you have please mention to your oncologist as they can sometimes reduce the dose, which can help. The other side effect from the steroids you take before and after the chemo can be not being able to sleep! I never had this issue, although have had sleeping issues constantly since finishing treatment....work that out! Tax wasn't pleasant but then none of it is, but you will get through it! Just 3 to go, you are nearly there Hun. Keep going! Listen to your body, rest when you need to and spoil yourself when you feel up to it! Wishing you all the best XXXX
Posts.Title: Just feeling a bit jaded!

Posts.Content: Hi Lynne1402, WELCOME to the club none of us wanted to join BUT you will find we are a very friendly bunch and hopefully you'll feel slightly less alone now you have found us! May I start by offering you a welcome...... Hug! Because at times like this you can never have enough hugs! Now how to help you feel a little less overloaded! Well now you have read all the information you can put it to one side and concentrate on getting ready for your holiday! Where are you off too? Breast Cancer doesn't spread that quickly, hence the reason they are letting you have your holiday! I know that this diagnosis is going to be on your mind, obviously. But try and allow yourself to enjoy your break. Then when you get back it'll be time to concentrate on getting through the next few months of treatment! Once the treatment begins its best to take things a day at a time! Not sure if you have been told what treatment you are having yet, but whichever order it goes in just concentrate on it one step at a time. If you think about everything all at once it really is overwhelming! As for crying.......well that's a good thing! You've been given some life changing Cr@ppy news of course you are going to be emotional. In fact over the coming months you are likely to go through a whole host of emotions! All of which are fine to feel so don't try and hold them in, just be kind to yourself and allow yourself to feel how you need to feel. Remember though that you are not alone. We are all here for you. Day or night there will be someone on here to offer advice, support or a virtual hug!  If there is anything you would like to ask about the Cancer or the treatment, then do ask! There will probably be someone who has answers to your questions! Above all else, remind yourself that having Breast Cancer is rubbish, BUT it's not the end of the world. You WILL get through the coming months! Yes it will be a tough few months, but we'll be with you every step of the way! IF you want us too! Hope that helps a little! Oh and may I pass a packet of virtual tissues, to help mop up those tears! You are going to be okay Hun. Sal xxxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Diagnised today.......feel a bit lost!

Posts.Content: Purplemarriane there’s not much we can do to make things better but it is the one place where you are allowed to say how it really is which lets face it is CRAP CRAP and more CRAP!  Sounds like you have a lot on your plate! So make sure you off load as much as you need too, we ALL totally understand. Oh and as for getting off lightly, a Cancer diagnosis is NOT getting off lightly whatever treatment you go through! It’s still a bloody tough thing to deal with both physically and emotionally. So please don’t try and compare yourself to others.  Good to hear you read the AWAKE thread, I trust we are entertaining you! But Please feel free to post on there, we allow you to moan as much as you want too! We let you have a laugh occassionally too, you might of noticed! So pop on and say Hi. Where are you based? We have a meet up coming up. It’s in Birmingham if you would like to join us you would be very welcome. Sometimes it’s nice to meet people and have a good chat and a hug. But in case you can’t make it or don’t fancy it here’s....... Sal xxxxxx
Posts.Title: Breast cancer the gift that keeps giving!

Posts.Content: Hi Hun, I was period free for just over a year, when I had what I can only describe as the period from hell. It came in time for my 40th birthday, oh what a treat! I had been on Tamoxifen for almost a year and so my 'period/bleed' needed to be investigated. But as you've only just started tamoxifen I'm not sure it can be connected!? How long has it been since your last period? If the pain is unusual for you, I would seek advice from your GP or BCN, but if it's really bad, maybe give the NHS line a call for advice! On a plus Zoladex will stop your periods completely! Although I know that doesn't help you now! Sending you a (((((((((gentle hug)))))))) xx
Posts.Title: First period after starting Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Hi,  I began Zoladex injections a few months ago, had 2nd one just over 2 weeks ago. My Oncologist told me I was likely to have a 'bleed' approx 2 weeks after my first injection and then my periods should stop! Well I am 2 weeks on from 2nd injection and am having another 'period' :-( I must admit other than a few aches and pains in my joints,  I haven't had any of the side effects that I was expecting. No night sweats and no hot flushes! Which is great but can't help feeling that means the injections aren't doing what they are supposed to be doing. I was on Tamoxifen for about 18months and the hot flushes were unbearable, so was expecting at least some flushes from this drug. Has anyone else on this injection continued with periods? I'm wondering if my body is still getting used to it, and that by next month I'll be back on moaning about hot flushes ;-) I will contact my BCN tomorrow and mention it, but just wondered if any one else had had the same reaction? Xx
Posts.Title: Zoladex and Periods!!

Posts.Content: Hi Judyr58, I totally understand where you are coming from. Those adverts make me cringe! Losing hair, through no choice of your own is VERY different to doing it to make money for charity. I am very grateful to everyone who helps raise money for Charity, but I do think there are better ways of doing it. I hated losing my hair back in 2013/2014 but having my sisters or mum offering to shave their hair too, would not of helped support me in any way! I think it's very difficult for charities to find ways of advertising and supporting without upsetting someone. So I suppose we have to learn to take a deep breath and look at the bigger picture. Which is they are making money for a very good cause. I for one hate the breast cancer month in October, when every time you switch on the TV/radio there is an advert about beating breast cancer and how we will win the fight etc etc. Breast Cancer is portrayed as something Pink and Fluffy!! Well it's not either of those to me, it's a disease that took away the life I enjoyed and loved. In return it has given me a life of uncertainty, full of treatment that I don't like or enjoy! But that I have to endure, if I want to keep living as long as I can. Not so Pink and Fluffy!!  Thanks for starting this post and being so honest, I think there are a lot of women who share these views, but are too worried to say anything, as we all know at the end of the day they are doing this for a good cause!  I personally enjoyed doing the Macmillans Night In, a chance to get together with friends and family and Celebrate Life  and just have a good time, while making money for a great cause! Wishing you all the best for the future xx
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Alex23 I started Tamoxifen two years ago and have just had my first period since and like you the pain is really bad. It is really heavy too. I am assuming this is normal. I don't know. Hope you feel better soon Hi Hun, not sure how old you are or what treatment you have had, but you need to mention this to your Oncologist/BCN! As bleeding like this needs to be checked out.  Yes it might just be your periods starting again, but they do say any bleeding after 12 months period free need investigating. As a tamoxifen can cause issues with the womb lining. I had a period just over 12months from my last and was sent to see the gynaecologist and then had an ultrasound and hysteroscopy, all ended well. So don't worry too much!  But please mention it to someone. In the meantime can I offer you an ((((((((((understanding hug))))))))) because I know how horrendous that first period can be  Hoping it doesn't last too long for you. Take Care and let us know how you get on xxxx
Posts.Title: First period after starting Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Hi Lisa, thanks for the reply. It's always good to hear someone else's experience of these things.  I will mention to my Oncologist, like yours he prefers injections to the surgery route! Which I am happy to agree with, as long as they are doing their job ;-) Think I'm more concerned because of my issues with Tamoxifen, and the fact I now have secondary cancer in the bone. Just feeling a complete lack of confidence right now. So needed a little reassurance. So thanks for taking the time to reply and share your experience. Wishing you all the best xx
Posts.Title: Zoladex and Periods!!

Posts.Content: Thanks Dimpsie, I will mention it to Oncologist at my next appointment. Period has been MUCH lighter this time, so things must be going in the right direction.  Wishing you all the best! Xx
Posts.Title: Zoladex and Periods!!

Posts.Content: Or just ignore? As I am worried that I am going to sound paranoid?!  I recently found a swelling in the area where the collarbones meet the sternum. It feels like it could be a Lymph Node. I felt it a few weeks ago and thought I would just keep an eye on it and mention when I next see Oncologist, as I only had a PET CT 6 weeks ago! So I assume if there was anything there it would of shown up on that, wouldn't it? I felt it again last night, I don't think it's any bigger but I can definitely feel it. I am so fed up with hospitals and doctors, but should I get it checked? Or would leaving it till my next appointment at the end of August be okay?
Posts.Title: Should I go and see GP or mention to BCN?

Posts.Content: I thinks it great that people have raised so much money, and I suppose you are never going to please everyone. Maybe they just need to look at the way they advertise or name things!  How about Shave to Save! Like has already been said there's nothing Brave about having your head shaved through choice.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Hi corolep, I think the only opinions that really matter are yours and your friend who you are wanting to support through her Cancer Journey! Could I ask, do you plan on shaving your head continually throughout your friends treatment? As her hair will fall out, approx 2 weeks after her first Chemo! It won't grow back for months......yours will start to grow back immediately! How does she feel about this? I know after treatment when I first went to get my hair, what little there was, coloured. I was surrounded by women with beautiful long hair, and I was so jealous. I personally would hate for a family member or friend to shave their hair off for me! But I would find it even harder to go through treatment looking and feeling worse each day, while my friend had hair growing back! I don't doubt for one minute that you are a wonderful friend, the fact you are asking the question shows that.....BUT....I would just make sure your friend feels okay, REALLY okay with you doing this! Wishing you all the best with whatever you decide, sending lots of love and positive vibes to your friend. Xx
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Hi Silverglades, I read your message and was quite shocked! I think the fact she went through breast cancer but dodged the Chemo bullet, makes this sound really strange! I think for most of us when we get the Cancer diagnosis, we think about death and then we think about losing our hair! It tends to be one of the biggest fears! So I find it really odd that she would choose this as a way to raise money! Now I obviously don't know the person and I am only speaking for myself, but I can't help wondering if she is doing it for the attention as well as making money?! Sorry if that sounds cruel. But I would question why someone who has been through Cancer would want to do this? If it was a man I wouldn't think so much of it. Maybe it's just me who thinks its weird for women to do this out of choice! But maybe some women don't think about their hair in the same way. As for whether you give money. That's up to you, but personally I would rather go and put the money in a collection tin, than support someone doing this. Xx
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Hi, the aches and pains will hopefully only last a few days, but make sure you take some form of pain relief! I was never a pill popper, but when the Tax truck hit, I was open to anything on offer! Soaking in a hot bath helped too. The taste buds for me, sadly stayed away for the entire time I was having Tax, everything tasted slimey?! It was odd. But they do return after its all over! I kept to simple foods and strangely enough foods like porridge and rice pudding were the best as they were meant to be 'slimey' feeling in the mouth.....if that makes sense? I also found sucking on sweets helped, not great for your teeth but that's life!  Oh and I found water was difficult to drink, I preferred adding some sort of flavour to it. It's a rough few weeks, but you will be at the end of this before you know it. ((((((((Gentle hugs))))))))
Posts.Title: Docetaxel (Taxotere) Aches & Pains!!

Posts.Content: That's exactly what this site is for Hun! We are able to help and support each other because we can all empathise! We know how it truly feels to be given this news. We also know how hard we all try to protect our families, not wanting to upset them! But the next few months is about you! If you are offered help then accept it! If you need time alone ask for it! It's all about finding the best way for YOU to cope with this. No two journeys are the same. We are here for the Good days and the Bad, if there is one guarantee in all this its that for the next few months you will be going on a rollercoaster ride of emotions like no other.......but we have all been there and we are all willing to sit along side you, for as long as you need us! Xxx
Posts.Title: Diagnised today.......feel a bit lost!

Posts.Content: Lisa_F, another....... From me! Sorry you find yourself here, but you will find it the most wonderful and supportive place! If you find yourself struggling to sleep please pop on to the AWAKE thread! It’s full of non sleepers and USUALLY there is someone on there to chat to or you can just browse through the pics! We call ourselves the Fruit Loops and we try to have a laugh as well as discuss more serious issues! We believe no one should feel alone on this crappy rollercoaster ride!  You have a tough few months ahead of you but everything is doable and there will always be someone on here who can answer any questions or concerns you have. But remember we are all different, no two journeys are the same. So if you read about someone having a tough time DON’T panic and assume you will be the same because it just doesn’t work like that!  Oh and 1 piece of advice DON’T use Dr Google! He’ll just send you spiralling out of control! Stick with Mac! We’ll help you through this.  Sal xxx
Posts.Title: Newbie looking for some gentle support

Posts.Content: FrancesW, I think you have worded that perfectly. How ever well meaning these people are I think they do need to concentrate more on bringing attention to the cause!  I am 3 years on from diagnosis but still feel uncomfortable seeing the Macmillan ads for this. It's a reminder I just don't need. I thought I was just being over sensitive, as I was recently diagnosed with secondaries in the bone, so already feeling emotional. But it's great to see that I am not alone in feeling that this way of fundraising just doesn't feel right. Sending best wishes to all ladies going through this xx
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Sounds like your Oncologist needs a kick up the backside! Fingers crossed your scan is soon and is clear!  What reason did the oncologist give you to explain the pain? Did you request a scan to settle your fears? Xx
Posts.Title: Is it bone mets?

Posts.Content: Stephen Merchant shaved his head to present the Crystal Maze! Not really sure why, other than to make him look a bit like the original presenter. Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Xxxxxx
Posts.Title: Uplifting things

Posts.Content: Hi Karen1908, if I were you I would take a list of questions when you next see your Oncologist, sit down and think about which course you think will best suit you. Then get the Oncologist to explain which choice is best for you and why? i don't want to go into full details of my journey, but you are welcome to message me privately. But I will say that this is an important decision and not one that you should be making, in my opinion! They are the experts and they should be telling you which option will give you the best chance of long term cancer free survival. The two types of drugs are very different which is why one is suited to pre menopausal women and the other to post! I wonder if you were offered Tamoxifen with Zoladex? As this could also be an option?! I don't envy your decision! Xxx
Posts.Title: Choice of medication?

Posts.Content: Hi Jowolfe, firstly may I welcome you to the group, none of us want to be here but it's a great place for support, advice and lots of virtual hugs. On that subject let's start off with a BIG WELCOME..... HUG! Because if there's one thing you will need on the upcoming journey it's lots of hugs. So, on to the serious stuff. Firstly may I reassure you that we have ALL been where you are right now and it's a VERY scary place to be! HOWEVER, it does get easier and things WILL calm down. Once you have a treatment plan to focus on you will start to feel slightly less anxious. The journey you are about to embark on isn't easy, isn't fun BUT it is however VERY VERY DOABLE and with the help and support of family, friends and us lot on here you will get through this Hun.  Now to try and reassure you that you won't be leaving your children for a long while yet! Breast Cancer is very treatable obviously depending on the type you have, will depend on what treatment you are offered. But whatever the test results are Hun there will be a treatment option. Even IF you were to be found with Secondary Cancer (which hopefully you won't) IT IS STILL VERY MUCH TREATABLE, and you should be here with your children for a long time yet! Now there is nothing you can do now other than to sit and wait for the results. But PLEASE stop asking Dr Google for his advice as he really is useless! Everything is out of date and it's all very much doom and gloom! While you are in these early stages and already feeling anxious and scared, stick with us! If there is anything you need to ask or if you just need a rant, go for it! There will ALWAYS be someone to help advise, support or offer a virtual hug both day and night! None of us can take away your fear, but we can promise you that we are all here for you and you will never be alone. I hope that helps a little. It's always difficult to know what to say because obviously nothing we can say will take away the fear and pain you are feeling right now! But when you look at your boys today, don't think about how they will cope without you, instead think about how you will show them how much you love them and that you will do everything within your power to get through the next few months, so you can be with them for many many years to come! They need you Hun as much as you need them right now! Together you WILL get through this! Take Care Hun, I look forward to getting to know you more over the coming weeks and months. Sal xxxxxx
Posts.Title: Coping

Posts.Content: Oh Jane, sorry to hear that. It's so frustrating when things are delayed, especially when you would of stopped taking it, had someone of mentioned it. I believe the recommendation is to stop it 2 weeks before surgery as it can affect blood clotting and could interfere with drugs used during surgery. So although frustrating at least they are making sure you have a safe surgery with no unexpected surprises. Fingers crossed you get a new date soon. (((((((((((BIG HUGS))))))))) xxxx
Posts.Title: Diagnosed and scared.

Mine was removed as soon as I had had my last dose of Tax, like you I found it a godsend BUT the skin around it really suffered. So I was pleased to get rid of it! Hopefully with all the right meds and the knowledge that the end is in sight, you will sail through the next few weeks! Well done on getting this far  (((((((((((GOOD LUCK HUG))))))))))) saved for people that really sound like they need it xxxxxxxxx

Posts.Title: Breast Changes 3 years on!!

Posts.Content: Hi Terry 37, firstly well done for getting through the 3 FEC as it sounds like you had a REALLY tough time. However the T part is very different and I know a few ladies who struggled like you on FEC and absolutely breezed through the T part! I however was the other way around, was fine on FEC and struggled with joint/bone pain on T. What I am trying to say is don't you think it's worth giving it a go? See how you get on? No one can force you but it seems a little counterproductive to stop before you know how it will affect you, especially as you have managed to get through 3 FEC, which shows that you are stronger and more determined than you give your credit for. You have done amazingly well. Now I will just offer you a MASSIVE........ HUG. Because I think you deserve it and it sounds like you could do with one. Only you can make the decision, but I really hope you give T a try before you decide. I know it's tough but please make sure you make the decision based on facts and not fear!  Wishing you all the best Sal xxxx
Posts.Title: Sickness Durung Chemo FEC

Posts.Content: Hi, just wondering if anyone else finds their breast constantly changing since having treatment? I thought mine had settled a while back, but in the last month my scar around my nipple has began to pull inwards and yesterday I noticed another area that is pulling inwards when I move my arms (I was shaving pits at the time) I don't spend all day checking out my boobs Anyway my 'logical' head says it's just the scar tissue/radiotherapy. I only had my Mammogram in June and a PET CT in August, so hopefully it can't be anything sinister. But I am so fed up of things constantly changing. They tell you to keep an eye and report any changes....well going on that theory I'd be calling them every week! I am currently on Zoladex injections so wonder if that is affecting my breast, also had surgery on my sternum back at the end of Feb so I suppose that might of created more scar tissue! Just wondered if anyone else has had the same issues and if things settled......eventually.

Posts.Title: Ideas on coping with backache....

Posts.Title: Crafts and BC

Posts.Content: I think we can probably all agree that the hospitals system with dealing with results really does need looking at. Although I would question whether your BCN was being dishonest in telling you you would receive the results over the phone. I know from experience that they don't like to do that....although I don't know why. I had a CT scan a while back, it was following a bone scan which showed a lesion in my sternum. They wanted to check that there was nothing else going on. So for me quite a worrying time. It took 3 weeks to get the results, even though the results would of been available after a week. This was due to the Oncologist being away and my BCN being away and the report needed to be discussed at the MDT before they could give results. I lasted 2 weeks before calling the general BCN line and requesting that someone tell me the results. No one called back. Finally I got hold of me BCN and after lots of tears and getting angry and explaining it was driving me nuts, she finally said "it's all clear, except for the sternum area"! When I asked why I couldn't of been told that weeks ago, she said because they aren't allowed to give results over the phone without the Oncologists go ahead. Ridiculous! So I wonder whether your BCN said that to appease you, then left the other nurses to deal with the back lash. Having said that, as she has said you can have results over the phone, I think they now need to do that.  Good Luck today I hope you get some answers. Xx
Posts.Title: Serously not impressed...

Posts.Content: suzie02 I am sending you the((((((((((((((((BIGGEST HUG)))))))))))) although won't squeeze too tight.  I am 3 years on from diagnosis and still have pain and discomfort in the breast, I also have a firm lump bigger than my original lump....but this particular lump is caused by scar tissue and isn't trying to kill me...so that's a positive! Are you on any hormone therapy, as I am and that is what is and has caused all my issues! I am currently trying out different painkillers to try and sort things out, but haven't solved the problem yet! (Although I have more issues now, so yours may be easier to solve) don't want to scare you! Only advice I can give is that you need to mention your concerns to your Oncologist/surgeon which ever you are seeing, once they are sure it's just nerve/healing pains, start looking at medication to help sort it. I tried so hard to 'cope' and 'ignore' things, but I really wish now I had just taken painkillers from the start, as it never improved and i was constantly told it would get better, so kept waiting another few months. Meanwhile I wasn't sleeping (still an issue) was constantly unhappy and ended up not feeling capable of working  life became one huge effort. Please seek help now and don't think you have to just put up with this, as my GP told me the other day, no one should be in pain when we have so many medications to help.  Good luck with everything, keep sharing, always happy to listen xxx
Posts.Title: Breast pain (STILL) 7/8 weeks after RT anyone ?

Posts.Content: Hi suzie02, I assume you have only been on Tamoxifen for a few months? So firstly can I suggest you try a different brand! My hot flushes were every 30mins day and night while taking a couple of the brands, but on one brand I was only having them every so often! So definitely worth trying to find a brand that suits you. I also tried a menopause magnet, which did help! But not sure how?! As for my other issues, that's NOT Tamoxifen based which is why I didn't mention it as I didn't want to worry/panic you. I was on Tamoxifen for 18months and it didn't completely work for me. So now I am on Zoladex injections. Which sadly have the same cr*ppy side effects, but if i don't have the injections I will have to have surgery to remove my ovaries and then probably be put on a different drug  So have decided to stick with this a big longer! All I can say is Tamoxifen made my life a misery and I was ready to give up after about 6 months! My Oncologist said if I could last out for at least 2 years he would of been happy. At 18months I was going to stop but the decision was made for me, as I was found to have one area of bone mets in my sternum. Although I was angry that I had wasted 18months of my life feeling cr*p I was pleased that I had stuck it out, as IF I had given up at 6 months and then discovered the bone mets, 1) there could of been more spread and 2)I would of blamed myself for stopping the Tamoxifen...and that would of been tough to live with! This drug is an amazing drug and it works for most people, but you don't need to suffer. All I can say is be TOTALLY honest with your Oncologist. List down all your issues, don't get fobbed off with things will improve, because yes they might....but right now you need help and support to deal with them! Having said that it's still very early days for you and so you might find things settle. So don't be too disheartened, be kind to yourself you have been through a lot! I hope I haven't said too much, or scared you! Because that's the last thing I wanted to do! Xx
Posts.Title: Breast pain (STILL) 7/8 weeks after RT anyone ?

Posts.Content: Hi Hun, I am also single and now living back with my parents....but I'm okay with that! In answer to your question, yes I am now classed as stage 4, which is pretty cr*p but not the end of the world.....or so people keep telling me. But it does mean I can't stop treatment now, so I have to learn to live with my side effects. So although I have NEVER been a pill popper, I am now willing to try anything that might give me some quality of life! It's alright people saying ladies with just bone mets can live for years, but what's the point if you aren't happy! Anyway if you want to find 'love' or a companion I am sure the right person is out there somewhere! You are still you, you are entitled to find the love and support you want and need. The right person will understand and love you for who you are!  so please don't give up! As for the bone pain, I still have painful ribs, it was almost definitely down to the Radiotherapy or age (but I'm only 41) The bone scan and PET CT were clear. So I can at least reassure you that having these pains although annoying can be nothing serious! Bone scans are very good at picking up bone mets! So if it was clear that is a good thing. As for tamoxifen brands, there are at least 3! Well that I tried. So definitely give them all a go and find the least annoying! Feel free to PM me any time, I know how rough this is and am happy to listen  don't try and do this alone. We are all here to support each other! Xx
Posts.Title: Breast pain (STILL) 7/8 weeks after RT anyone ?

I'm on Zoladex injections now, and am having the same sort of side effects! So this time I am taking other drugs to try and settle the side effects. My body clearly loves Estrogen and isn't happy about it not being there! I think changing to letrazole will 'probably' have the same side effects or maybe worse? OR maybe it will suit you better, you won't know until you try?!  Could let you try it for a couple of months? See how you go? Although must admit the idea of bone thinning would scare me, as the one plus on tamoxifen is it doesn't affect the bones, in a negative way! Sorry I've not been much help! Posts.Title: Very bad flushes

Posts.Content: Hi Lucy, I was on Tamoxifen for 20months. After about 9months my periods returned, nightmare periods! I had major bleeding and cramps. As it had been a year since my last period, they did an internal can to check things out! I had thickening to the womb lining, which then needed investigating. I had a hysteroscopy, which showed fibroids and cysts. They took biopsies of the womb lining. Everything was clear and was put down to Tamoxifen side effects.  I think the problem with Tamoxifen is that no one seems to agree on whether or not it has any affect on your periods. I was told by the Oncologist that Tamoxifen puts you into early menopause, and in the same week told by the Gynaecologist that it doesn't?! Work that out?! Sorry that doesn't really help you, but just wanted to share and let you know you aren't alone!  I'm on Zoladex now, which has put me into drug induced menopause, but even on that I still have weeks where I feel like I'm going to have a period, it's weird! Just think our poor bodies are confused! Sending a (((((((friendly hug))))))) xxx
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen Troubles

Posts.Content: Hi Batfinkcaz, Well you answered your own question correctly, you are definitely NOT a wuss! I'm not sure people realise how BIG that needle is! I think Gay's suggestion about getting the cream to put on an hour before your jab is a good idea! Especially if you think the sugery is making things worse! As Gay says some nurses are better than others! My first injection about 20months ago was given at the hospital and I didn't feel a thing.....so cocky me went away thinking, wow what an easy treatment great I can cope with this! Next injection at the GP surgery.......OH MY GOOD GOD, I almost jumped off the couch, brought tears to my eyes would be an understatement! But since then she's got better and better!  I have my injection every 3 weeks, so I've given my nurse lots a practice! Now we chat and laugh about it and I find it okay! Yes I have had a couple that have REALLY hurt! But then it's over with for another few weeks! I come on here I moan I say I can't do it and I never want to go back and 3 weeks later I am lying on the couch getting the jab! The more you relax the easier it is! Slow deep breathes and think of something nice! But If you are really concerned then definitly try the cream! Wishing you all the best, remember we are here if you need us. Posts.Title: Pain after biopsy, normal?

Posts.Content: Hi all, so it's been one of 'those' weeks, getting together with friends and family, which leads to lots of questions about how I'm doing. So in answer to the question I replied; I'm doing well Thanks, looking forward to Christmas and then starting my new job in Jan, health wise things are stable, so yes pretty good! Now I have had the gentle hand to the shoulder, tilted head and responses ranging from, Really? Are you sure? I'm here if you need to talk! Or Well things will never be quite the same will they? Or the real belter of a response, but it must be hard trying to smile when you are dealing with the big C! So am I wrong to be genuinely feeling okay about things? Yes I have off days, but on the whole I feel pretty good! Yes I have aches and pains and can't sleep, but I try not to let that effect me. These people have made me think I should be facing the fact the end is near....so I should be concentrating on having fun, while I can!! I'm sure the end is a LONG LONG LONG way off, so am more than happy to take each day as it comes and to get on with living a normal life. Which for me involves going back to do the job I love and to have fun, but in the same way everyone else does, book a holiday if and when I want to. Not because I'm not sure how many I have left! I don't want or need a 'bucket list' as the way treatment is changing all the time and the fact my Cancer is stable, to me means I have plenty of time to do everything I want. For now I just want 'normality' a little bit of Hospital appointment anxiety and scan results anxiety thrown in every few months, but on the whole I am and I want to be 'normal'.......might seem boring to some, but after the last few years, 'normal' is good In the last few days I have ended up feeling like everyone around me seems to think I'm not facing reality......which in their eyes seems that having secondary cancer is the end of the world! I admit it's no picnic in the park, but it's certainly not the end of the world. But after all the 'looks' and 'comments' I wondered if I was missing something!! So long as I don't step in front of a bus any time soon, I think I can safely assume I'm still going to be around to annoy them next Christmas!! Or at least I hope I will  xxxx

Posts.Title: Odd coloured breast?!

Posts.Content: Hi, there is information available online which actually states that hormone therapy has a bigger effect on hormone positive cancer than Chemo! I had Chemo, as the cancer had reached my Lymph Nodes. BUT just 2.5yrs later the Cancer was found in my sternum! It wasn't there on the bone scan I had before I started Chemo. So it grew either after Chemo or during?! Either way the Chemo didn't prevent my spread. Obviously it may have prevented it getting anywhere else, who knows!  But the side effects of Chemo can be long lasting and with no node involvement I would be inclined to NOT have Chemo, if you are happy to do that. Worse case scenario IF it did return you would still have Chemo as a treatment option! You have to do what feels right for you. Good Luck xxx

Posts.Title: its the weekend ;-)

Posts.Content: Hi Hun, firstly i totally understand your anger/frustration at what you are going through. But wanted to reassure you that your surgeon wasn't lying to you. They were going on the information they had, which would of been the mammogram and ultrasound reports/pics! Which can only give them so much information. It's not until they operate that they can really see the extent of what's happening inside. It's very possible for one cancer to hide behind another! Then it's only through testing the tissue removed that they can see whether or not they had clear margins. It's not like cancer cells stand out from normal looking cells, especially when they are just starting out! I can empathise with how you feel. I had bone mets discovered in my sternum. As this was the only area of spread my oncologist suggested surgery to remove the area of bone! Which in theory will leave me NED no evidence of disease. So I went for it, a long surgery, painful recovery and 2 weeks later told they didn't get clear margins :-( my cancer was still there and still active! So all that pain for nothing!!! But it was worth a try! I'm sure those surgeons were disappointed that they didn't get it all, as were yours! But they have to weigh up the pros and cons of removing enough tissue without removing too much healthy tissue! Sorry that was so long winded, hope it made sense. Wishing you all the best for your mastectomy. Hopefully it's the last surgery you will need for awhile ...... (((((((((((Supportive and understanding hugs)))))))))))) xxxxxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Why?

Posts.Content: Hi met428, just read your reply and realised how alike we are! I have been drip fed information throughout my journey! I went from being told Surgery and Radiotherapy would be required. To surgery, chemo and node removal surgery would be required!  I spoke with my BCN and explained that I needed to be given ALL the information, this first became an issue when I received a copy of the letter that gets sent to my GP in it was more information than had been discussed at my appointment. I was angry and confused and started to lose trust in the people who were treating me. I then had a bone scan 2 years after my first one. On it my sternum lit up! My oncologist said he wasn't overly concerned and was happy to leave it and look again at the next scan in 3 months! Once discussed at the MDT it was decided it needed investigating and of course as I had already worked out for myself it was bone mets! But it took from Nov 2015 to Feb 2016 for them to finally admit it was bone mets! Up to then they tried to placate me with, it might not be, it might be an old injury etc etc......I knew deep down it was mets but they just seemed to pussy foot around, somehow thinking this would help me!  I'm more of a give me the worse case scenario so I can be prepared person, I know that doesn't suit everyone. But I do think Oncologists or our BCN's have to treat us as individuals and ask us how much information we would like! So I totally get where you are coming from and all I can suggest is you try and get them to understand how you want to be treated, how you need the information and you are more than capable of dealing with it! Now may I offer you an Understanding........ Take Care Hun, hope things start to settle for you xxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Why?

Posts.Content: Crystaljuju Hi Rach1969  My hospital has just sent me information saying they no longer consider it necessary for me to avoid injections/BP and bloods on the affected arm. They say there's no evidence to suggest it does increase your lymphoedema risk. No doubt your physio will be practicing good hygiene and sterile conditions so the risk is very very low. I would say though that cortisone isn't known for being great as a one off and it will take many shots to be effective. love Julia x  Hi Julia, I recall you mentioning this on another post. But just wanted to add, one of the ladies on the secondary group, recently went through Chemo and had a PICC line in her unaffected arm. So she needed blood pressure to be taken on the arm where nodes had been removed. She has now developed Lymphoedema in that arm.......coincident? Or down to Cancer? Or chemo? I don't know. But I think if it was me, I would still opt to use the unaffected side for blood pressure and blood tests etc! xx
Posts.Title: Frozen shoulder, Cortisone injection, lymphedema risk.

Posts.Content: Hi, sorry you are having such a rough time! Chemo really is the Pitts! But you are almost through the first half!  The T part has its own issues, but is very much doable. Sadly the taste issues can continue through T too! But I was never sick and my head didn't feel anywhere near as fuzzy as it did on FEC!  I recall hitting the "I can't do this" point after round 2 but it was due to a bad experience......but even though you feel like giving up, in a few days you will start to feel 'human' again, and you will go along to your next Chemo and the next until it's done.....because however cr*p it is right now, it's hopefully kicking the cancers butt and giving you the best chance of a happy and hopefully cancer free life! So allow yourself a little time to feel sorry for yourself, acknowledge that you feel like cr*p, but then remind yourself, you WON'T feel like this forever! In a few months time you will be posting on here telling other people to stay strong and keep going, because you will remember how hard it was!  We have all felt how you feel right now.......but we got through it and so will you! If I could reach through the computer and hug you I would,  (((((((((((((HUGE YOU CAN DO THIS HUG)))))))))))) xxxxxx

Posts.Title: Strange pain after slb

Posts.Content: Hi, just wanted to reassure you that your little one will be fine and of course your bond won't be affected. I have worked as a nanny for years and the children have been left in my care, for anything up to a week while the parents were away on business. I promise you on their return the parents were met with squeals of delight and big hugs. You will have to explain to your little one that you are sore and to be careful, but the trick is to make sure you keep yourself protected, as we all know how little ones can appear from nowhere and always bump you where it hurts. So sitting at the table with her sat opposite or next to you, is always a good position. Remember you can still show your love and affection, just in different ways. As for pain, I didn't have that sort of surgery, but I'm sure they will give you plenty of pain relief, don't suffer in silence, they won't know you are in pain if you try to be brave!  Now try and keep busy for the next few days, spend some special time with your little one. It'll be you that misses all the hugs etc little ones nana and daddy will keep them happy   You are going through this so that you can have many many many more years with your little one, so please don't think you are doing something to emotionally hurt your child, because you aren't xxxxxx

Posts.Title: life after chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Hun, Do you regularly check your breast? If so are these masses/lump new. If so go to your GP or speak to your BCN if you have one! It's probably nothing and I assume you had a mammogram at the beginning of your cancer journey. If so both breasts would of been checked! Its not impossible for another lump to of formed, but it's just as likely to be normal breast tissue you are feeling. I know I have very Lumpy breast which makes checking them really tough. So the best advice I was given is: IF IN DOUBT, CHECK IT OUT!!!!  Better to be safe than sorry! Sending you a BIG......... SUPPORTIVE UNDERSTANDING and CARING HUG xxx

Posts.Title: I THINK I NEED MORE SLEEP.......

Posts.Content: Okay, time to admit that I need more sleep, or more oestrogen, now as oestrogen is trying to kill me I suppose sleep is the one to work on! Now how did I come to this conclusion, what made me realise that this was an issue.....hmmmmmmmm let's look at the evidence! 1) I gave a lovely baby fish pie to the works cat instead of the baby! 2) I made a cup of tea and didn't put the teabag in! 3) I made a cup of tea, with teabag.....but no water! 4) I ran a bath without putting the plug in! 5) I looked everywhere for my scarf......it was around my neck! 6) I plugged my phone in to charge, without plugging in charger! 7) I dressed as a super hero, putting my undies on the outside! (Error discovered before I left the bathroom, thankfully! Super Londonlass wasn't quite ready to come out to the world yet I'm sure I could come up with other examples, but I think this makes the point! So clearly I have issues, now I used to blame the Chemo, then I blamed the Tamoxifen, now it's lack of oestrogen and sleep......I suppose at some point I might have to admit that I am just a bit of a FRUIT LOOP  But if nothing else, although frustrating at the time it always gives me something to giggle about after the event, it also appears to make others smile and laugh.....so as we all know laughter is the best medicine, I thought I would share my 'mishaps' with you all. Anyone else wish to share any 'mad moments' or is it just me!!!!!!  HAPPY SATURDAY TO ALL xxx
Posts.Title: I THINK I NEED MORE SLEEP.......

Posts.Content: Hi Fleet1, i’m Not sure I can offer much advice on anxiety as it’s not something that I have really suffered with. But I just wanted to remind you that you are going through a huge, life changing experience right now and trying to cope with both the physical and mental challenges that this disease and it’s treatments throw at you! So PLEASE don’t be giving yourself a hard time because you aren’t that active and fit person right now! At the moment your ‘fit’ body has been hit by the Chemo train and that is a huge shock for any body to deal with! But once you are through the Chemo and you are back to eating properly and slowly start to exercise again you will start to see glimpses of the ‘old’ you! So please don’t think this is forever! This is just a moment in time and it will pass!! Although it is pretty shitty when you are living in that moment...... it DOES get better! Promise! Right now I think you just need reminding that you are doing great! If I was there I would offer you a supportive hug, but this will have to do..... Take care and just take things One day at a time! You CAN get through this. Sal xx

Posts.Content: Hi Toony, I was covered in unexplained bruises while on tamoxifen. Oncologist checked bloods etc, but concluded it was a side effect, a rare one but somehow connected. Bruising stopped as soon as I came off tamoxifen! Strangely enough started again when I started Zoladex injections, but only lasted a few months. Worth discussing with your oncologist or GP and to get your bloods checked, but it can be tamoxifen related. Hope that helps xxxx

Posts.Title: 6 or 8 cycles

Posts.Content: Hi littleone31, I just wondered if your Oncologist/Surgeon had mentioned the Oncotype DX test? where they send away part of your lump and test it to see if Chemo would really benefit you. It's only done on patients that are node negative BUT I am pretty sure when it's in just the sentinal node that's classed as negative! In fact I wonder why you were given a full clearance :-( I think some hospitals just do things differently. However I think it would be worth asking the question about the Oncotype test. As it could come back that Chemo wouldn't benefit you! Having Chemo just because of your age seems a bit like over treatment when they have tests available to help make a more informed decision!  Its just a thought, and I might be wrong about the sentinal node thing. But might be worth looking in to? I know I would want to know that Chemo was really necessary before I went through it.  I'm going to tag in Dreamthief, as he's the fountain of knowledge and will tell me if I am wrong but also give you more information if I am correct! I suppose the other question is what type of cancer you had I'm assuming it's ER+ and HER- otherwise Chemo is a must! Also whether you are based in the UK! Hope I haven't confused you too much! Sal xx

Posts.Content: Hi mumof3, firstly Welcome! But sorry you have joined the club no one really wants to join. I think something you said might help you put all this in to perspective, "when I found out I had BC I developed a pain in my back" so it wasn't there before?  I recall when I was first diagnosed that with every ache and pain my brain went in to overdrive, clearly the cancer was running wild through my body.....obviously it wasn't!  Your cancer has been caught early and is slow growing, which are both good signs! It's highly likely your backache is just that, backache from over doing it or just getting older....I have had back ache on and off for years, but scans have shown its just wear and tear! I would keep up with over the counter pain relief and see how things go. IF in a few weeks things are worse or not improving then speak to your GP again and see if they will take a closer look.  In the next few weeks I'm sure you will notice every little ache and pain, but it's normal perfectly normal! Just remember one thing, you are currently Cancer free, No Evidence of Disease.....that's good, it might still feel you are in the cancer whirlwind, but you are through the surgery, which I hope went well for you, and the rads and tamoxifen will hopefully ensure it doesn't come back!  You've been through a big surgery, give yourself time to heal physically and mentally. It all takes time. But try not to over think everything. Back ache is very very common, it doesn't mean it's cancer related.  Hope that helps a little! Have a special (((((((((welcome hug)))))))) xxx
