Posts.Title: Nipple tassels or no nipple tassels?

Posts.Content: Hi Breasty-besty , sorry to hear you are dealing with this extra worry! However I do think you need to bare in mind that doctors, particularly GP’s will always air on the side of caution. I have had numerous scans and tests to ‘rule out’ mets, even when I myself was 99% sure it was down to other things!  Is it possible that the Herceptin is causing the headaches? Or blood pressure? Or stress? There are so many things it could be and in fact that it’s more likely to be than Brain Mets!  Not sure if this will reassure you but I have Bone mets and when I have my 3/6 monthly scan they only scan from neck to knees! I would think that indicates that they feel Breast Cancer is more likely to spread to the main organs/bones before the brain! Obviously I can only talk from the point of someone with ER+ Breast Cancer! As for the wait for a scan IF the GP has marked it as urgent you should get a scan within the 2wk guide line, although this can vary from hospital to hospital. The same with results! Ideally you will hear within 2wks, although 3wks is more realistic in most hospitals! I know it’s easy to say Don’t Worry but worrying won’t change anything it’ll just make you more anxious and possibly increase the likelyhood of you having more headaches! Try and keep busy, do things that make you happy and don’t over think things!  REMEMBER your GP is just being thorough! Good Luck Hun and let us know how you get on! Sal xx

Posts.Title: Worlds Biggest Coffee Morning

Posts.Content: Hi Rach, sorry you are having a tough time with arm pain! Going on how you describe it, it sounds very much like cording! Now usually you can see or feel what looks like a cord inside your arm, hence the name. But I suppose it's possible to have a cord that is deeper down and therefore not visiable!  Lymphoedema doesn't tend to be painful, it's more of a heavy achy feeling in your arm and the swelling is quite noticeable.  Nerve pain tends to be stabbing pains or burning pains! So my guess would be cording and the best thing for it is stretching and massage, until the cords snap! Now it is possible to do this on your own sometimes BUT the fact you can't see or feel the cord isn't going to make that easy! So you need to contact your BCN explain that you think you have cording and she will arrange to see you and get an appointment with the Physio! Alternatively see your GP. But the sooner you get it seen to the better! I hope that helps a little! Sending you a (((((((((((gentle hug))))))))) Sal xxx

Posts.Title: Feelings.......

Posts.Content: It's that festive time of year where we are all thinking about life and the future. Whether living with cancer, having treatment for cancer, or moving on from Cancer. So wanted to start a thread that could show what we are thankful for over the last year and what we would wish for for next year. It's something the children I used to look after did at school and I will never forget 2013 when the little girl I looked after gave her wish to me and wished.....that my best nanny gets her hair back in 2014 so I can share my hair clips with her  I shed a few tears on that day! So my 2 Thanks!! Thankyou to my family, friends and online friends who have stood by me over the last year. You have helped me laugh through the bad times (even though it hurt after surgery) shared smiles through the good times and given me a kick up the backside when I've needed it. Thankyou to Maggies online and Macmillan for helping me survive the year following my secondaries diagnosis. The help and advice has been amazing and I wouldn't of got through the year without you. I WISH that 2017 will be a more stable year for me, that I will settle in my new job and really start living again. A year full of genuine smiles and laughter! So that's me done.....anyone else want to join in? Xx
Posts.Title: Two thanks and a Wish...

Posts.Content: Hi Brighty1, just wanted to say...... Really sorry that you find yourself here, especially as it seems you have had the year from hell. Sorry to read that you lost your mum, I’m sure dealing with Cancer on top of grieving is REALLY difficult.  However you have done the right thing coming on here as there will always be someone on here to offer support, advice or just a listening ear, which we all need sometimes! There is also the helpline number that you can call if you want to speak to someone, or the ask a nurse section if you have a specific medical question. Although if you start a thread with a question I am sure there will be someone who can answer it! That’s the amazing thing about this site, we all have different paths on this journey and therefore the chances are someone will be able to advise you! Of course your first place for advice should be your medical team, when they return from their holidays! I know that feeling well I swear my Breast Care Nurse seemed to be away on holiday each time I had a question to ask!! It was very frustrating but I used online support as a way to answer my questions while waiting for her to return! The greatest thing about online support is that there is usually someone around Day or Night! I started a thread called AWAKE, which began as a place to chat in the early hours when I couldn’t sleep but as the time has gone on it’s turned into a place where we put up funny/supportive pics and we have a laugh! I know right now you probably feel that there is nothing to laugh about. But believe me you will find your sense of humour again, you need too as it’s much nicer to laugh when you can!! Feel free to pop on the AWAKE thread and say hello, you will be very welcome! Once you have started treatment there is a monthly Chemo thread and a monthly radiotherapy thread. But those you can learn about once you have a treatment plan in place! I promise you that once you know what the plan is you will feel a little bit more at ease! The next 12months won’t be easy but they are doable. You learn very quickly who your true friends are and I would suggest that you accept any help that you are offered. Don’t feel you have to do this alone, you don’t get any awards for being ‘strong’ or ‘brave’! Be as open and honest as you can about how you feel and don’t be afraid to ask for help!  I have probably babbled on enough! Especially as I reallly just wanted to say Hi! But please use this site as much as you need to! Ask lots of questions or rant or enjoy making new friends. It won’t be long before this site becomes part of you every day life. I for one have made some amazing life long friends! I hope you can too. Look forward to learning more about you. Stay in touch. Sal xxxx

Posts.Title: Experts Needed

Posts.Content: Hi Lou, well that sounds like CR*P news. Although I will add please don't assume the worse until you know for sure! There is a lady from this site who was diagnosed with mets to the liver following a CT scan. But when the scan was viewed by a liver doc he asked for more scans and eventually ruled it out as NOT cancer related. Now I am not saying that to give you false hope as that's the last thing I would do. But I am a great believer in making sure of the facts before worrying too much! Easier said than done I know!  Have you been scanned before? So they have another scan to compare It too? If so that's slightly different, although clearly they aren't 100% sure if they are going to biopsy! Now IF it does turn out to be Mets which makes you stage 4.....IT IS NOT THE END OF THE WORLD...... although yes it will feel like it!  People can live a long happy life, so don't be thinking you will be leaving your children anytime soon, because it's HIGHLY unlikely! There are many many treatment options. I found out a few weeks ago that my lovely neighbour who had breast Cancer a year before me, has been living with secondaries to her liver for the last year! You wouldn't know, just like me she just gets on with life! Yes you have bad days, but doesn't everyone. But with the support of family, friends and the lovely people on here and on the secondaries board you will never be alone! Happy to be here every step of the way, whatever the results we shall be here for you! Now I think I have probably bored you to sleep! So shall end it there. Other than to add an extra.......... Supportive Hug! Because you can never have too many hugs! Oh and just to finish, if you have any issues sleeping over the next few days/weeks of uncertainty, please pop on to the AWAKE thread! It might not help you sleep but it'll give you a giggle! Take Care Hun, Sal xxxxx
Posts.Title: Scared, I think my breast cancer has gone to my liver....

Posts.Content: Hi Lou, there are times on this cr*ppy journey, when there is nothing anyone can say or do to take the pain and fear away! But on these occasions I like to share this....... Because no one can change what's happening, all we can do is reassure you that you will be okay. You will find a way to get through this and we will be with you whenever you need us! As for positive stories. When you are ready pop over to the secondaries board and you will find some amazing people who have been living with this illness for years. I'm not going to lie to you Lou, because that's not fair, you need honesty! Having Secondary cancer is a minefield of emotions. You can go from super positive to super depressed in a few hours, in my experience! You can have days/weeks when you actually don't think about Cancer and other weeks when it's all you think about! Life will go on and you have to accept that life now involves hospital appointments/treatment forever! Not an easy concept to grasp! BUT you also need to remember that this is by no means the end of the world. There is so much they can do these days. Okay no one is going to promise you will reach 90! But then maybe just maybe you weren't destined to reach 90 anyway! Don't be drawn in to asking HOW LONG, because the truth is they don't know! We are all different we all react differently to treatment and we all have different lifestyles!  My Cancer has now been stable for over a year! I am only on an injection every 3 weeks and lots of pain meds! I suffer with fatigue which is tough! But I am still working 3 days a week. I am slowly learning to listen to my body, which in turn means my body gets time to rest when it needs too. Learning to conserve energy for when you want a nice day out, is important. But these are all things we can talk about, if and when you want/need to. For now take slow deep breaths and remember that whatever news you receive over the next few weeks, we'll be here to offer, support, guidance and some great big hugs!! Thinking of you Hun, your new online Buddy, Sal xxxxx

My appointments then moved to 6monthly. But I didn't last long on that, as my bone mets were discovered. But if things had remained okay, I believe my hospital would of done 6 monthly checks. Posts.Title: Whats the normal follow up after treatment finishes.

Posts.Content: Hi Aneesa1, sounds like the wig person has left you confused. To be secondary cancer, the cancer needs to be in another area, for example bones, liver, lungs etc. If it is contained in the breast and axillary lymph nodes its primary cancer! But if you are unsure I would call your breast care nurse if you have one, or speak to your oncologist!  I think the wig person should stick to sorting wigs, and leave medical diagnosis to the experts!  Sending you a (((((((welcome hug))))))) hope you are able to get the correct information soon xxx
Posts.Title: Primary cancer and secondary cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Emma, firstly take a deep breath and relax.........Okay. Now on to  your questions. Most places these days are a one stop clinic, where you will see a breast surgeon who will examine you and ask questions about when and how you found the lump. They will send you for a mammogram, ultrasound or both! Now if they feel it is necessary they will ask if it's okay to do the biopsy while you are already lying down for the ultrasound. The biopsy can be uncomfortable, but shouldn't hurt too much as they will use an anaesthetic to numb the area. Then you will go back in to see the surgeon who will answer any questions that you might of thought of. At this point SOMETIMES depending on scans and depending on the surgeon, they might be able to say we are certain it's not cancer or we are 99% sure the results will show it is cancer....either way it will probably be approximately a week before you know for sure!  Yes it will seem like the longest week of your life, but remember whatever happens and whatever the results, we are all here for you and IF it turns out to be Breast Cancer it is very treatable, so don't panic. To finish may I offer you a calming....... Welcoe Hug! I am hoping your journey here is short. But if not you will find us a really nice bunch of people! Good Luck Hun.  Sal xxxxx
Posts.Title: New and nervous

Posts.Content: Hi Confusedbear, sorry you find yourself worrying about and dealing with fatigue, I know how horrid it is! It's frustrating when our bodies don't seem to do what we expect them to do But I think fatigue is definitely to be expected after all you have been through, and continue to go through with the tamoxifen. Are you having any sleep issues? As obviously this could cause the tiredness through the day? I know when I was on tamoxifen I was waking through the night! The other thing you could do if you are really concerned, is to see your GP and have a blood test? Just to check all is okay there? Sometimes low iron levels can cause fatigue? Maybe worth checking it out.  Hopefully you will find the solution to your fatigue, but it is still early days and your body has been through a lot. So allow yourself time to get back to 'normal'!  Hope that helps a little. Sending you a (((((((supportive hug)))))) xxx

Posts.Content: Hi, keep an eye on your temperature any sign of a fever call the Chemo unit. If you continue to feel unwell call them just to get checked out! Don't take any chances. As for crowds, I avoided any form of crowds during Chemo! My theory was it was better to be safe than sorry. Posts.Title: It doesn't get any easier.....

Posts.Content: Hi Sally37, welcome to the group and Well Done on getting through the last 12months, we all know what a rough ride that can be!  The simple answer to your question is of course YES you can say no to AI drug, it's your body and you can put into it whatever you wish! However before you make the decision I would certainly make sure that you have spoken to your Oncologist and collected as much information as you can! It really should be an informed decision! Have you considered that the brain function could also be related to Chemo? The term Chemo brain gets used a lot, but it is real and I know many of the men and ladies on here have experienced it both during and after any Chemo treatment!  Menopause can also affect brain function, although I don't know whether you had already gone through the menopause before treatment! I think the most important thing to as yourself is, IF you stop the drug and the the Cancer returns in the next few months/years, would you regret it? Would you blame yourself? Or would you be at peace with your decision?  If you feel that you would feel okay and be able to live with that, then I think you have your answer! I am a great believer that quality of life can be just as important as quantity. But you have only been on the drug for 5months and so maybe before you stop entirely you could: try different brands? Look at what other drugs are available? Change the time of day you take the drug? All small changes that might or might not help, but that are maybe worth a try IF you haven't already tried! I am the last person to tell you not to stop as I was driven almost insane while taking Tamoxifen. So I totally understand how hard it is. But having been diagnosed with secondaries just 'before' I stopped taking it! I have always questioned whether I would of been angry at myself or blamed myself, if I had stopped the drug and then they had found the secondaries! You need to do what's best for you, which only you know! But really think about it and think about how you would feel should the worse happen! Which hopefully it won't! Good Luck with whatever you decide! (((((((((HUGS))))))) Sal xxx
Posts.Title: Can I say 'no' to post breast cancer treatment drugs?

It's not that far away, but I need to really get my head round the idea, that I 'might' have to take these drugs, I might just have to face my fear and give them a go!!  2 lovely ladies have shared their good news with me today, could it be my turn to have some good news too! Or will it be my turn to put my big girl pants on and take the drugs I need to hopefully keep me stable for a bit longer!! We shall see xxx
Posts.Title: It doesn't get any easier.....

Posts.Content: WHEN WILL I LEARN........... To not believe a word my BCN says I emailed her this morning, just to check my scan results had been reported. I even said I don't expect her to tell me the results but would at least relax a little, knowing I'm not going to my appointment tomorrow for nothing! She replied almost straight away, and said....... I'm sorry but I was busy in clinic yesterday so haven't had chance to look?! But they will be discussed today at the MDT and I will ask the doc if it is okay for the information to be passed on to you before your appointment tomorrow. I will email you later to let you know! So my immediate thought was, why didn't she just look on the computer and say yes it was in or no it wasn't! But maybe she didn't want me to bombard her with questions, so fair enough! I left for work thinking I would at least come home to a message saying its stable, if nothing else! If there was something else to discuss then I would at least be prepared, but obviously I was hoping for the email/call to say all is stable! Came home and checked messages, absolutely nothing  no good news, no bad news, no comments on I'm not allowed to say anything, absolutely nothing I shouldn't be surprised really, as I know how unreliable she is, but on this occasion she knew how anxious I was, so why didn't she say something......anything!! I'm now left feeling like tomorrow isn't going to bring the most positive news, because surely if it was stable she would of called me, wouldn't she? Or maybe I am over thinking it and she genuinely forgot, bloody annoying but not the end of the world!  Well at 11.40 tomorrow I will find out! I am desperate for it to be stable but sometimes life throws us curveballs, as I've already found out!  MOAN OVER! Xxx

Posts.Title: Treatment finished :-)

Posts.Content: Hi Jane, totally understand how you feel. I had a very tender breast when I was due my first mammo following treatment. Like you I was dreading it and I hog myself into a real state! However it wasn't as bad as I thought. I took pain relief an hour before my appointment and I explained to the radiologist how much pain I was in. You MUST tell them. They will do their best to make it as comfortable and as quick as they can. Slow deep breathing worked for me, as well as reminding myself that it was all going to be over in a few minutes! I'm not going to lie it was uncomfortable, but it wasn't nearly as bad as I was expecting! So try to reign in those thoughts. Keep reminding yourself why you are having this done and more importantly that it'll be all done before you know it! Oh and if you need to cry DO! They will totally understand! Don't feel you have to be brave! Just turning up takes Courage, but holding in emotions is just an added pressure that you don't need! Sending you the (((((((((((((BIGGEST HUG)))))))))))) Please leg us know how you get on! Xxxxx

Posts.Content: Hi Lottie8, I can't help you with your question on the Herceptin as I am HER-! However I can certainly understand feeling scared. I think we have all had those moments when life feels out of our control and there's nothing we can do to stop it! However I can also reassure you that you are not alone in all this, there are lots of us on this forum all different ages and at different stages of treatment. We all support each other, advise each other and always offer virtual....... Hugs.  You have been through a lot and continue to do so, you are entitled to feel however you need to feel. Just because you are in your seventies doesn't mean you can't be scared. I'm in my 40's and I have moments when I am terrified.......but they don't last long. You learn to take things one step at a time and when you feel yourself whirlwinding out of control, come on and share how you feel. The only people who can truly understand how you feel are the people who are going through it or have been through it! So lean on us! We are always here for everyone! If you find yourself awake at night, pop over on to the AWAKE thread! There's usually someone on there whose awake and willing to have a chat, or you can just look through some of the funny pics! Yes believe it or not, we laugh as much as we moan and cry, in fact I think we laugh more :-) Keep going Hun. You will get through this. Whatever happens there will be treatment options! Just put one foot in front of the other and get through this, one day at a time! Sal xx
Posts.Title: Everything in my life topsy turvy !

Posts.Content: Well in a weeks time I will receive my latest PET-CT scan results. This will be my 4th lot of results from a PET-CT, but I've also had numerous other scans and results.  When I began this journey I always thought (stupidly) that things would get easier, that eventually I would get used to the scans and the waiting for results! But it doesn't!  I have secondary Breast Cancer, so I suppose that puts a different spin on things. Although my last scan showed things were stable, that was in November! It's highly likely that things will still be stable and that's what I keep telling myself........so why is there always that little voice saying BUT WHAT IF?? I'm trying to put it to the back of my mind (failing) as I know I can't change the results, so what's the point of worrying? But I suppose worrying is all part of this cr*ppy disease!  So lovely ladies, as I work my way through this very very long 7 days of torture, any ideas on how to fill my time so I don't have time to over think things?? Adding to my stress is that I know that my results will be available on Friday, when I have an appointment to chat to my BCN but she's already said she's not allowed to talk to me about results  I do understand they have policies to follow, but I still think it's RUBBISH and a bit cruel! But that's life!!  Right, on with the day. Off to work xxx

Posts.Content: HI ALL, after numerous sleepless nights drowning in sweat and some horrendous days reaching boiling point, I thought it might be time to bring this post back for anyone who missed it or for those who weren't in this position last time round but can now truly understand!  WELCOME TO THE HOT AND SWEATY CLUB:  IF YOU HAVE TIMES THROUGHOUT THE DAY WHEN YOU LOOK LIKE THIS, THEN THIS IS THE PLACE FOR YOU! SHARE YOUR TRUE THOUGHTS AND FEELINGS ON DEALING WITH THOSE NOT SO JOYOUS HOT FLUSHES!  ********************************************************************** HI just need to say that the longer I am on this journey the more I am wondering how it ever became "PINK and FLUFFY? Almost 3.5years on this journey and I still haven't found the pink fluffy bit?! So I am beginning my own version, which will be.... RED and SWEATY! (Was going to be RED HOT and SWEATY, but that sounded like a title of a porn film) whoops!!!!! Now I admit it doesn't have quite the same sound about it and doesn't sound quite as glamorous! But it is more realistic of my experience over the last 3 years! Going from freezing cold to boiling hot in 5 seconds is NOT fun! Although those people not going through it don't understand how frustrating, embarrassing and exhausting it is! I'm thinking we could start our own olympics!  EVENT 1: The cardigan on and off race!!  EVENT 2: Wipe away sweat with no one noticing EVENT 3: Find something to waft (GP surgeries provide pamphlets) EVENT 4: Downing a glass of cold water as quick as possible EVENT 5: Duvet on Duvet off!! One of my best events! EVENT 6: How quickly you can get out of a crowded shop! (Ronstar) EVENT 7: Endurance, dressing with a frozen shoulder (Callie69) EVENT 8: Sheets off, Sheets on in under 2 mins (middle of night bed change) EVENT 9: Thermostat up, thermostat down (Rach1969) EVENT 10: Window open, Window shut (Rach1969) EVENT 11: Fan on, Fan off! EVENT 12: Stringing a whole sentence together (Bunty-ann) EVENT 13: Spelling and recalling simple words (Bunty-ann) EVENT 14: Icecream eating challenge....to cool down! (Croxley) EVENT 15: Washing hair out of an open window (Sammy) EVENT 16: Controlling Anxiety (Sammy) EVENT 17: Wig On, Wig Off (bougiecat) EVENT 18: Head scarf on, Head scarf off (bougiecat) EVENT 19: Nodding off, Brain says No! Nodding Off, brain says No Chance! Baton race! (mccaca) EVENT 20: The Hoovering Striptease!! (helsbels18) Please feel free to add any other EVENTS!  Now obviously I have written this as a bit of fun, I feel I can do that as I am dealing with this everyday and I know how unbelievably hard it is! So come on ladies, don't sit back and struggle with this alone! Come on and share your Sweaty thoughts and feelings! It won't solve them, but it sometimes helps to know that others are struggling to cope too!  I recall when I first suffered with hot flushes my mum used to joke about me taking my cardigan on and off, I took it for so long and then snapped! She was quite shocked at how frustrating hot flushes are, and obviously she has been through the menopause! People don't understand that drug induced hot flushes are far worse than normal menopausal flushes! (Although I'm sure some ladies struggle with normal menopause to)! They are very frequent and never ending, or that's how they feel! Between us we must be able to share some 'funny' or 'embarrassing' stories to show each other that we are not alone and that how ever horrible this is, we must fight hard to keep smiling and laughing! So let me think of my funniest tale.....hmmmmmm there are so many! But one that sticks in my head is when I was having a particularly hot moment, and the little boy I looked after had walked into the kitchen, he did an about turn and walked back in to the living room and said to his sister....."quick come quick she's melting"  He had been looking at candles at school all week talking about how they melt when lit  Bless his heart I couldn't stop laughing! Kids just say it how it is! Now I'm hoping someone else has a story to tell, or I am going to feel very silly......but if nothing else I hope this post will make someone smile and feel less alone through this sh*tty time! Xxxxx

Posts.Content: Hi, I am currently on Zoladex injections although I have them every 3 weeks. At one point I was offered surgery to remove ovaries, but having just had surgery on my sternum and feeling rough, I decided I couldn't cope with anymore surgery at that time. I then found that the Zoladex didn't cause too many side effects, compared to my struggles with Tamoxifen it was a breeze! So then I didn't want to rock the boat, I am scared that removing ovaries might cause more severe menopausal symptoms.....of course it may not! It's very much a personal choice, you need to do what feels right for you. The injections are no problem, if you get a good nurse you don't even feel it! But obviously surgery means it's dealt with, and apparantly it is a simple surgery! Good Luck with whatever you decide. Xxx

Posts.Content: Had to share this one with you all, as if nothing else it made me smile. Something I have struggled to do lately! So I have an Oncology appointment booked for November. The plan is usually that I have the PET CT either the day before or morning of my afternoon appointment. So appointment came through for the Thursday of the week of my Oncol appt. Oncologist only works a Tuesday afternoon. So I contact BCN and ask if she could change it, or if easier I would. She said it was no problem and better for her to do it, as if necessary she could change my oncology appointment. So she emailed me back and said all sorted, my scan would be at 4pm on the Tuesday!! My Oncology appointment was at 1.30pm?!  So I was seeing Oncologist for scan results, before I actually had the scan.......now that's impressive  Then she had a day off so said another nurse would sort it, that BCN told the scan unit that I needed an appointment on the 14th Oct....so today!  I spoke to the scan lady today and she very happily changed the appointment to the Monday before my Oncology appt. No problem at all. She went on to say next time, call her directly......as it'll be a lot less stressful So assuming my BCN hasn't invented time travel....the moral of the story must be........IF YOU WANT A JOB DONE PROPERLY, DO IT YOURSELF   This is not a criticism of BCN's as I know some of them are very good and very supportive. I have just had issues with mine and this just made me laugh! Which made a change from crying! Xxx

Posts.Title: Popping in to say hello

Posts.Content: Honest answer Sacha is that YES for some people it is. BUT for many people like Carolyn, it's not so bad......although still not fun I worked as a nanny throughout my Chemo, I was doing nursery runs and school runs on foot, in the morning, at lunchtime and in the afternoon. On my feeling rubbish days, which I can probably count on one hand I asked favours from nanny friends or parents of other children to see if they could collect rather than me going out again! Or I caught the bus there and back to save a little bit of walking!  I'm not going to lie, it was tough and for those few months my social life in fact any life other than hospital appointments or work, were non excistant. But I wanted to continue working as it made me feel I was still in control, and it gave me something to focus on and get up for each day. Before I began I was worried about the sickness, which I never got! The sore mouth, never got and the hair loss, which I did have as I chose not to use the cold cap!  You have to REMEMEBR that people don't come on here and start a post saying CHEMO IS SOOOOOOOOO EASY! Because we all know what a reaction that would get from others who don't find it so easy. People who suffer come on for advice and support which is why it seems that chemo is so horrific. But just be reassured that for every horror story there are probably 100 positive ones. Sadly none of us know before we start how we will be affected. But the first step in my opinion is to go into it with an open mind. DON'T look for side effects, be prepared with everything you need but don't talk yourself into things! Who knows you may be one of the 'luckier' ones. But if you aren't there are plenty of things that can help you, so be honest with your team and tell them if you have any issues. Most things can be helped. But the main thing to REMEMEBR is it's not forever!!!!! Wishing you all the best for your chemo and offering you a ((((((supportive hug))))) xx

Posts.Content: Morning CARDBOND, try not to jump ahead of yourself. No point wasting time and energy over something that might not happen. I know that's easier said than done! IF you are diagnosed I would suggest you ring the helpline and talk through your money issues with them. Alternatively there is a benefits advisor on the Maggies online, who is amazing and can talk you through what you are entitled too.  So calm down, take a deep breath. What will be will be. Posts.Title: In panic mode

Posts.Content: Hi Jojo4, the size of your lumps might affect their decision on wether to do a lumpectomy or mastectomy, if it's Cancer. But they wouldn't not treat it. They may decide to do Chemo first to reduce the lumps. As for aches and pains, that's totally normal. Your mind is going into overdrive and there isn't much you can do about it. Try and keep busy so you don't have so much time to think about it, and yes I know that is easier said than done. Wednesday probably seems a million miles away right now, but nothing is going to change over the next week, so try to reign in those thoughts. Whatever they find, cancer or not will be treatable, and once you know what is happening and you have a treatment plan in place you will begin to feel more in control, which hopefully will help you to relax. Sending you a ((((((((Big hug))))))) xxxxx
Posts.Title: Large lumps

Posts.Content: Jojo4 Thank you London lass. Very reassuring.  Do you have a view on chemo or surgery first?  Breast preservation isn't an issue - I'm at the stage where I want everything gone.  xx My view has been to just do what is recommended. I had surgery first as my lump was 2.5cm and they had originally said I would have a lumpectomy and then radiotherapy. But as it was found in my lymph nodes, I then had surgery to remove those and then Chemo.  I am sure every hospital has its own system, so wait till you have your results and then discuss things with the 'experts'.  Hope you have a lovely birthday tomorrow, definitely a nice distraction  xxx

Posts.Title: My Night....

Posts.Content: Hi Gay, at my appointment a few years ago! I was taken in to go through a questionnaire of the usual questions, personal details, medical history (which you would think they'd have) and an explanation of what was going to happen. Then taken through and given a gown to put on.....still to this day I struggle with which bloody tie is meant to be tied first! Then in to the CT scanner, where they scanned and then 2 nurses/radiographers asked if I was happy for them to do the tiny tattoos.....don't think I had much choice?!  They were a tiny pin prick nothing painful at all. Then on my way out they needed a photograph to put on my records! Not sure why?! Then I went home. I was then called back a week later to discuss things as my heart and lung were in the treatment area, so I was re scanned using a breath hold technique! Sorry I can't help on the implant side of things, but hope that helps a little. Xxx

Posts.Title: My Night....

Posts.Content: XjulieX, TOTALLY NORMAL and UNDERSTANDABLE! So DON'T bd so hard on yourself! You don't need a kick, but you definitely need...... We have all been there and in fact 5years on I still have days like that! Your body has had a huge amount to deal with and you were busy concentrating on getting through every step of the treatment! Now the active treatment is done you have time to really 'think' about what you have been through and how it has affected you!! It's not nice but sadly it's a step you have to go through, just like all the other steps!  Allow yourself time to grieve the old you, and time to accept the new! You might not have the same energy levels and that's normal! Don't forget your body is still going through treatment Tamoxifen is no picnic in the park! It can have some horrid affects on the body and mind! Low mood can be to do with tamoxifen as well as everything else! You need to concentrate on you! Give yourself time to feel however you need to feel! Shout and rant on here! But NEVER think you are being stupid feeling whatever! Because I can guarantee you that 99% of us, have been there!!  Take a deep breath Hun! It WILL get better! Xxxxxxxx

Posts.Title: Aux Nodes clearance

Posts.Content: Hi Lizzy4u, I had exactly the same issues as you. I lasted 20months but that was only because my oncologist kept pushing me to keep going, his view was the first 2 years were the most important. I won't go into what happened with me as it doesn't help you. I will however say there are other options! Zoladex injections to shut down your ovaries, or surgery to remove your ovaries? Then you would be put onto one of the post menopause drugs, like Letrozole. Worth discussing?? However, I think you have to bare in mind that all of these treatments will cause menopausal symptoms and of course it's worse for us as we are being forced into menopause! Out of interest have you tried changing your brand of tamoxifen? Sounds silly but different brands can have different side effects! Worth discussing everything with your oncologist, the more information you can get the better. You need to be able to make an informed decision. At the end of the day it's your body, your life and your decision! I know how it feels to feel so old and unhappy! Sending you a (((((((((((((((BIG HUG)))))))))))))) xxxxxxx

Posts.Title: Test day today!

Posts.Content: Hi Shellian, firstly it sounds like you could do with a...... Hug! I can totally empathise with how you are feeling and I can definitely reassure you that it is perfectly normal! There is most certainly no written rules on how long it takes to get over Breast Cancer! For some they have treatment and bounce right back! Others take months others years! I was one of the ones who took years to finally admit that what I had been through was horrid and that I was ANGRY, angry at the Cancer for messing up my life! Nothing was easy anymore, it had taken so much from me and I had to try and learn to accept what I had been left with! Well with the support of people on here and the lovely ladies on Maggies and in the Maggies and Force centres. I now feel in control of my life! I thought I could do all this alone! I have never needed others to help sort my feelings, but on this occassion I couldn't go it alone! We all need to ask for help at some point. You my lovely have made the first step in getting back on track! You are opening up to us, about how you really feel! Well done Hun! So what now? Well maybe chatting to the helpline might help, or if you feel you are depressed seeing your GP to discuss things? Seeing a counsellor might help? Or just sounding off on here for a bit might help! The main thing is to realise that this is 'normal' you have been through a huge thing and you aren't through it yet. So please be kind to yourself. Yes you need to find a way to help you through this, but it's nothing to be worried about. I promise you most of us have been where you are! I hope it helps to know you aren't alone. Please keep talking! Don't be afraid to say whatever you need to. We are all here for you Hun, day or night someone will be around. Take Care Hun. Sal xxx
Posts.Title: 2 years after diagnosis so down

Posts.Content: Hi Jo, I can join you at being 'special' the one time In my life I would rather not of been! I had a PICC 3 years ago and remember clearly going in and hearing how easy it was to put in and it wouldn't take them long etc etc Had a nice male nurse, he tried and tried and tried, each time he introduced the needle the vein collapsed. Goodness knows how many attempts later, he admitted defeat. My whole arm was black and blue! The next day I was due to have chemo in the afternoon, so he said to go there first and he would try again. This time I drank lots of water and he placed warmed towels over my arm before he started, he also with my permission put the needle/line in without a local anaesthetic, he had found that my veins were constricting as the anaesthetic was going in, which apparantly can happen sometimes. Anyway about 15mins after arriving there, my PICC line was in, and I was off to X-ray to check its position! Had no problems after that. Will always remember the look on his face when he saw the bruise on my arm the following day, especially as he had told me what a simple procedure it was  These things happen. Hopefully tomorrow will work out better for you. Drink lots and try to relax xxxxx
Posts.Title: PICC line aborted

Posts.Content: Hi, I had to have this investigation as my periods returned a year after Chemo finished! An ultrasound showed a thickening to my womb lining, which is a concern when you are taking Tamoxifen! (Not sure if you are) I had the procedure under a GA, and it was fine, the doctor was able to tell me on the day that all looked fine, although they still had to send off biopsys to check! They are always super cautious when you have already suffered from Cancer, and although that is frustrating and worrying, I suppose we should be grateful that they are keeping a close eye! Good Luck, I hope all goes well xx
Posts.Title: hysteroscopy

Posts.Content: Hi Juju68, have to be honest with you it could be either or both! I completely empathise, fatigue is a complete nightmare. Made worse by the fact that no one else can see it or understand it. Outwardly we look fine, but inside we are struggling to get through the day! What I would ask/suggest is have you had a blood test recently? If not it's worth checking that your iron levels are okay and your thyroid. Both of which can cause fatigue.  Sadly I have no answers on how to solve the issue, other than to rest when you need to but also make sure you get some exercise during the day as its been proven to be good for fatigue......sounds silly I know! I also know how hard it is to force yourself to go for a walk when all you want to do is sleep or sit down, but it's worth trying. Sorry I can't help more, but at least you know you aren't alone. I can offer you a supportive...... HUG xxxxxxxxxxxxx
